LEAD: Robert Kramer, a vice president at Drexel Burnham Lambert, was detained last Friday by United States Customs agents as he was leaving the Bahamas for failing to declare $88,000 in cash and securities in his possession, Drexel officials confirmed yesterday.

LEAD: More Spring Lamb Traditionally, consumers look for spring lamb for their Easter menus or for Passover around this time. The official season for spring lamb, however, is considerably longer. The period in which these lambs must be slaughtered to qualify for the Federal designation ''genuine spring lamb'' extends from March 1 through early

LEAD: IN Noel Coward's ''Blithe Spirit,'' a middle-aged novelist named Charles Condomine must contend with the outspoken ghost of his not so dear, departed wife. The spirits who hover over the play's revival at the Neil Simon Theater are another story. Watching this flat all-star ''Blithe Spirit,'' one can only think back to Broadway's last misbegotten all-star assault on the same playwright - the Elizabeth Taylor-Richard Burton ''Private Lives'' of 1983.

LEAD: FOUR New York State chardonnays and three seyval blancs shone last week at a tasting sponsored by the New York Wine and Grape Foundation. All were 1985's, and three of the chardonnays came from Long Island.

LEAD: As chairman of the Semiconductor Industry Association's public policy committee, George Scalise has been instrumental in persuading Washington to impose trade sanctions against the Japanese. But Mr. Scalise, who is also senior vice president of Advanced Micro Devices Inc., the Sunnyvale, Calif., chip maker, said he views the sanctions as ''incentives'' for the Japanese to comply with the trade agreement signed last July 31, not as a punitive measure.

LEAD: Tatyana M. Malinovskaya is the party boss in a county where reindeer outnumber people, 200,000 to 26,000. Her office in this gold-mining town in northeastern Siberia, opposite Alaska, is closer to Washington than to Moscow.

LEAD: The day was going to be relatively quiet, but it turned into a morning full of revelations after Rick Rhoden's scheduled appearance in a minor-league game was called off following an overnight storm.

LEAD: A group of prominent New Jersey Republicans announced today that they had formed a committee to raise money for a possible campaign for the United States Senate by former Brigadier General Pete Dawkins.
LEAD: The Japanese Government has begun to consider a broad range of measures to defuse the intensifying trade crisis with the United States.

LEAD: The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra announced today that it would perform in the Soviet Union this spring, marking the first time in 11 years that an American orchestra had appeared before Soviet audiences.

LEAD: The Marine Corps has arrested a third enlisted man who served as a guard at the American Embassy in Moscow on suspicion that he violated regulations against social contacts with Soviet women, the Pentagon said today.

LEAD: At the curb, a handful of airplane passengers look for transportation to downtown Bombay. Across the way, in the airport parking lot, a hundred or so taxi drivers take the morning sun. A naive traveler attempts to hail one but is studiously ignored. What's the secret?

LEAD: THE son and grandson of North Texas cowboys, George Peacock was to be nothing else. That's all he ever knew, breaking horses, roping calves and driving wagon teams even before he went to school. He began as a wrangler, turning out at 4 A.M. to pen the horses for the other hands. Today, at the age of 52, he is the foreman of the Nail Ranch, one of the region's most respected cowboys, punching cows by day and writing checks by night as ranch manager.
LEAD: A bill that would direct colleges to actively investigate rapes on campus even if the victims do not file criminal charges has been introduced in the State Legislature.

LEAD: MORE than 500 pounds of ripe, juicy papayas were sneaked into Los Angeles last week and unobtrusively delivered to supermarkets. The papayas had been treated with radiation to kill fruit flies, and while that is legal it is also controversial. The growers were trying to get the fruit to shoppers without alerting the National Coalition to Stop Food

LEAD: About 30 newly converted Ayoreo Indians set off from a Protestant mission in northern Paraguay in late December to contact ''unreached'' members of their tribe whose tiny jungle settlement had been spotted from the air by a missionary pilot.

LEAD: The evangelist Oral Roberts, who had said God told him he would die unless he raised $8 million by the end of March, wound up a 10-day prayer vigil today with a final entreaty to followers to send money.

LEAD: Albany's legislative leaders seem intent on embarrassing themselves by denying Governor Cuomo's $5 million budget request for a Commission on Government Integrity. What do the legislators have to hide? Their refusal to cooperate only whets public curiosity.

LEAD: Born with a silver spoon in its mouth and bred to be noncontroversial, the National Museum of Women in the Arts will open to the public April 7 after a ceremonial ribbon-cutting by Barbara Bush, the wife of the Vice President. The first museum devoted solely to female artists in a historical context, it occupies a handsomely renovated landmark building - formerly a Masonic Temple - at New York Avenue and 13th Street, two blocks from the White House.
LEAD: On your mark - sneakers tied, galoshes pulled into place.

LEAD: A woman will allow her former husband, a homosexual, to have overnight visits with their two daughters, ending an 18-month legal battle that began when she demanded that he be tested for the AIDS virus, lawyers said today.
LEAD: Feb. 6, 1985 - Mary Beth Whitehead agrees to be artificially inseminated by William Stern. Their pact stipulates that she will relinquish all rights to the child in return for $10,000.

LEAD: Senior Israeli officials were divided today in their assessment of reports that Moscow would soon permit large-scale Soviet Jewish emigration directly to Israel and more freedom of religion for Soviet Jews.

LEAD: EVER since he was a youngster growing up in this North Texas town of 2,000, the son of a county road worker and sometime cattle hauler, Billy Gilbreath wanted to be a cowboy. At the age of 20, on the Lambshead Ranch, he is a new recruit to an old trade.

LEAD: If advance dealer orders are any indication, Chevrolet's new Corsica and Beretta will be hot sellers. But even if those initial orders do translate into consumer purchases, the General Motors Corporation knows only too well that a fast start does not guarantee big sales over the long haul.

LEAD: I WAS fascinated to read recently how Cornish hens were popularized in this country. In the 1950's, Victor Borge, the pianist and comedian, raised the birds on a farm he owned in Connecticut and sold them dressed and ready for the oven. They are a cross between an American fowl, the Plymouth Rock hen, and a Cornish or Bantam rooster or small gamecock.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: He has won more National Collegiate Athletic Association championships than any other coach, and now, after 16 titles, Dave Williams has decided to retire. The 68-year-old Williams announced he would leave the University of Houston on Aug. 1 after 36 years as the golf coach. When he began at Houston in 1952, the Cougars had never won a tournament.

LEAD: THREE HUNDRED abandoned ''boarder babies'' who have been living in the hospitals where they were born, some for months, while awaiting foster care may be placed by November, according to a plan announced by the city last week. But they still wait, although not without special attention: a program giving the elderly a role in their care has recently begun.
LEAD: A health care company reported Monday that it had started the first testing in humans of a manmade version of the clotting substance missing from the blood of most hemophiliacs.
LEAD: In the marketplace it is rumored that Ronald A. Kovas, a director of the JWT Group, is marked for even greater greatness at the company.

LEAD: Three elaborate and fanciful towers that have graced Manhattan's skyline for more than 50 years became official landmarks yesterday with the designations of the former New York Central Building on Park Avenue and the San Remo on Central Park West.

LEAD: The chairman and vice chairman of the Senate intelligence committee said today they planned to raise detailed questions about Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d's handling of the Iran-contra affair at hearings next month on the nomination of William H. Webster as Director of Central Intelligence.

LEAD: Crude, overt racial bigotry has again come out of campus closets and onto the quads. Reports of public slurs, cross-burnings, even outright physical conflict now ring routinely from schools throughout the country, including some of the most prestigious. A society's universities ought to be among its chief civilizing influences.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Federal Government has notified a California hospital that it plans to end Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement there because of the transfer of uninsured poor patients from its emergency ward to other hospitals.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: AN evening-long work by Meredith Monk and Ping Chong that opened last night at the Joyce Theater, ''Paris/Venice-Milan/Chacon,'' is a magical, intricately woven and many-layered excursion through time. Strange sounds and music and words in several languages form a haunting aural backdrop for this voyage.
LEAD: The Peach Bottom nuclear plant in Pennsylvania was ordered shut down today by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which said it found control room operators sleeping on duty.
LEAD: A woman who destroyed a bikini-clad snow sculpture with a hatchet because she found it sexually offensive must answer for her actions in court, the chief city prosecutor said today.

LEAD: In a move likely to stir opposition in the United States, General Motors of Canada Ltd. today received an interest-free loan of $220 million (Canadian) from the governments of Canada and Quebec in return for guaranteeing the continued operation of an auto plant.

LEAD: Andrei D. Sakharov told Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain today that it was vital for all nations to give support to the moves for a more open Soviet society espoused by Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote by which the House of Representatives today voted to override President Reagan's veto of the highway bill. A yes vote was a vote to override the veto. A no vote was a vote to sustain it. Voting yes were 248 Democrats and 102 Republicans. Voting no were one Democrat and 72 Republicans.

LEAD: Representative Tony Coelho, the Californian who is one of the House Democratic leaders, predicted here the other day that the party's 1988 Presidential nominee may be chosen in a ''brokered'' convention next summer in Atlanta.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court in San Francisco blocked the $860 million merger of Delta Air Lines and Western Airlines last night, just hours before it was to go into effect. The court said the merger would be prohibited until an arbitrator settles a dispute over union representation.
LEAD: THE THANATOS SYNDROME. By Walker Percy. 372 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

LEAD: The bond market was recovering some of Monday's sharp losses when it was shaken anew late yesterday after Citibank raised its base lending rate to 7 3/4 percent, from 7 1/2 percent. Chase Manhattan quickly followed suit.
LEAD: Pat LaFontaine scored twice, leading the Islanders to a 4-3 victory tonight over the St. Louis Blues in a battle of playoff-bound teams.

LEAD: The Japanese Government submitted legislation today that would deny visas to foreigners who are known to carry the virus that causes acquired immune defficiency syndrome and are considered ''likely to spread the virus to many people in Japan.''

LEAD: IN the beginning, there were khaki-colored drill cloth trousers, the kind worn by the British Army when it occupied India in the 19th century. Then came British Khaki, a clothing manufacturing company opened seven years ago by Robert Lighton, whose family owns men's stores.

LEAD: Detectives, searching for a motive and clues in the slaying of a Parking Violations Bureau hearing officer, are focusing on about 900 cases handled by the officer in recent years, police officials said yesterday.

Going into last night's games, the North Stars were a point ahead of Toronto and tied with Chicago in a struggle for the last remaining playoff spots in the Norris Division.

LEAD: Imagine a New York City cockroach with chutzpah. It has wings, a preference for bright lights and a sex drive so lusty it can produce 75 million offspring a year. That's the Asian roach, Blatella asahinai, and it has been vacationing in Florida this winter since arriving on cargo ships from Asia. It is expected to move north.

LEAD: Segregation in New York Patterns of racially segregated housing, which began easing two decades ago in the New York City area, are reasserting themselves. Page B1. LEAD: The Senate today overwhelmingly approved a housing bill costing up to $38.3 billion that is strongly opposed by the Reagan Administration as too expensive.

LEAD: Kevin D. Murphy, a partner of KMS Corporate Brokers, a Wall Street bond brokerage concern, died of a heart attack Friday at Bellevue Hospital Center. He was 48 years old and lived in New York City and Newtown, Conn.
LEAD: NEW YORK CITY'S annual summer jazz festival -formerly Newport-New York, then the Kool Jazz Festival, now the JVC Jazz Festival - will be back this year beginning June 19.

LEAD: The House of Representatives today easily overrode President Reagan's veto of the $87.9 billion highway bill, leaving the Senate as the battleground for a major test of Mr. Reagan's power in the final 22 months of his Presidency.

LEAD: COUNTLESS words have been written by now about the joys of Creole and Cajun cooking. The popularity of those foods - from Cajun popcorn (deep-fried crawfish) to jambalaya and shrimp Creole - continues apace. Blackened redfish has become an obsession for some; others consider it a plague.

LEAD: Koreans in New York There are, according to the Korean Grocers Association, about 1,000 Korean greengrocers in the city (and 1,000 Korean fish markets, 1,000 laundries, not more than 50 Korean grocery stores and about 45,000 Koreans). This familiar and recent New York phenomenon is the subject of today's talk in the Asia Society's continuing series of Wednesday lectures, ''Discover Asia: Asian-Americans in New York City.

LEAD: ANY time the stock market takes a terrific jolt - as it did on Monday with the Dow Jones industrial average plunging 57.39 points - investors like to know what Wall Street's technical analysts see ahead.

LEAD: The auction price of one of van Gogh's ''Sunflowers'' paintings paid Monday at Christie's in London -$39.9 million, roughly four times the previous record for a work of art -brought reactions of shock and bafflement yesterday among museum officials, dealers and other art professionals.

LEAD: The ruling yesterday in the Baby M case settled the specific question of who is granted custody of the child, but other courts and state legislatures will continue to face the larger question of whether surrogate-motherhood agreements are legal.

LEAD: Students at the nation's 57 historically black private colleges are bearing the brunt of Federal grant cutbacks and are falling deeply into debt to finance their educations, according to a new study.
LEAD: Gary Heidnik, the man charged with murder after the police found body parts in his refrigerator and women chained in his basement, was charged today with a second count of murder.

LEAD: A picture caption in the Arts and Leisure section on Sunday gave the incorrect network for the debut of ''Roxie'' tonight at 8 P.M. The half-hour situation comedy will be shown on CBS. Also, a cast change was announced after press time; Jack Riley, not Jerry Stiller, is featured.

LEAD: Baby M Called Melissa by the Sterns, Sara by the Whiteheads... had her first birthday last Friday... described as happy, alert and resilient. Mary Beth Whitehead 29 years old... dropped out of high school at 15... married at 16, had two children before she turned 19... signed a surrogate agreement with William Stern in February 1985...
LEAD: Moody's Investors Service yesterday introduced a new index of corporate bonds that it hopes will eventually become the basis for a new futures contract on the Commodity Exchange.
LEAD: The stock and bond markets began to recover yesterday from the dollar's steep drop against the yen.

LEAD: At the annual meeting of the Cable Advertising Bureau, which drew more than 1,000 interested parties to the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, most of the talk had to do with the positive changes that have resulted from the deregulation of the industry, the growing involvement of system operators in programming and the emergence of marketing as a strong force.

LEAD: More than a year and a half ago, the governing board of the Smithsonian Institution divided sharply over whether to continue owning stock in companies that do business in South Africa. Some members argued that a body as closely identified with the American nation as the Smithsonian ought to sell such stocks so as to set an example of opposition to racist policies.
LEAD: The GAF Corporation made a takeover bid for the Borg-Warner Corporation yesterday, offering $46 a share, or $3.17 billion.

LEAD: Dome Petroleum Ltd., the financially beleaguered Canadian oil company, said yesterday that it had lost $2.2 billion (Canadian) in 1986, about $15.5 billion (United States) at current exchange rates. The loss appears to be the largest annual loss ever reported by a Canadian business.
LEAD: Anna Quindlen is on vacation. Her column will resume April 8.

LEAD: Western diplomats said today that military equipment abandoned by Libyan forces retreating from northern Chad was believed to be worth half a billion dollars.

LEAD: A new two-year contract proposal that would pay Roger Clemens a $1.5 million base salary in 1988 was rejected yesterday by the Boston Red Sox. However, General Manager Lou Gorman said, ''We want to keep the line of communications open and see if we can work something out'' to get the right-handed pitching ace back with the team, which he left March 6.

LEAD: Vinny Testaverde, the Heisman Trophy winner, is expected within a week to sign a contract with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers that would make him the National Football League's third-highest-paid player, according to The Associated Press. Bob Woolf, Testaverde's attorney, said, ''I'm very optimistic of making an agreement, although we don't have one yet.

LEAD: Two goals 15 seconds apart in the last period, including the third in the game for Perry Anderson, led the Devils to a 5-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

LEAD: TO many Americans, rice is rice. It comes in a box with short but intimidating directions. When it's cooked, you eat the part that you didn't burn with some other kind of food that has some kind of taste. The fact is, to many Americans, rice is boring.
LEAD: The trouble with April Fool's Day in New York City, of course, is that there's no way to tell who's kidding and who's not.

LEAD: Orders to American factories for manufactured goods, led by heavy demand for military equipment, shot up 4.3 percent in February, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the best showing in five months.
LEAD: West German Government officials denied today that there were plans to free a Lebanese hijacking suspect rather than extradite him to the United States.
LEAD: Citibank raised its prime lending rate to 7 3/4 percent from 7 1/2 percent yesterday, the first increase by a major bank since June 1984.
LEAD: What this nation needs is an Official Fool. ''We have plenty,'' you say. ''The Federal Government's full of them.''

LEAD: The National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians and NBC, which employs most of that union's 2,500 members, were continuing negotiations last night in the face of a strike deadline of midnight P.S.T. (3 A.M. New York time).

LEAD: In this state where basketball is more than just a game, the Indiana Hoosiers came down from Olympus today, greeted by some 15,000 fans in a deafening welcome-home celebration for the national collegiate champions.

LEAD: Wheatland, the foundation started by Ann Getty and Lord Weidenfeld that has sponsored conferences on the opera and on the symphony, said today that it planned also to hold conferences on literature.
LEAD: The Social Security fund that pays for Medicare hospital benefits improved over the past year but still faces bankruptcy shortly after the turn of the century, the fund's trustees said today.

LEAD: IN a demonstration of cooperation seldom witnessed in the highly competitive worlds of broadcasting and electronics, station owners and major electronics companies are banding together to save AM radio.

LEAD: Leslie Roberts, who dropped out of college and became a top broker for E.F. Hutton & Company and Merrill Lynch & Company, has been sentenced to 15 years in prison for defrauding his uncle of millions of dollars.
LEAD: The Justice Department is opposing recent court orders that court-appointed special prosecutors are exempt from certain laws on conflict of interest that cover department employees.

LEAD: Real differences over sea boundaries and oil drilling rights no doubt carried Greece and Turkey to the edge of military conflict in the Aegean. But the speed with which this storm erupted, and then evaporated, suggests it was artificially seeded by political rainmakers. Certainly the spat has helped Greece's populist Prime Minister, Andreas Papandreou: he roused cheers on the right by denouncing Turkey, and on the left by threatening to close down an American supply depot.

LEAD: Less than a month after the Tower commission wrapped up its investigation of the Iran-contra affair with a long report, at least one key staff member of President Reagan's blue-ribbon panel is heading for a job at the White House.

LEAD: United Nations members and voluntary agencies pledged $207 million in emergency aid for Mozambique at a conference in Geneva on Wednesday, officials said today. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar began an appeal for more than $244 million in food and medical aid last month. Mozambique officials say the country is continuing to suffer from starvation caused by a prolonged drought.

LEAD: Leftist guerrillas thoroughly infiltrated a major army base before destroying it Tuesday, according to two senior military analysts here. They added that the American military adviser who was killed in the raid had probably been sought out by the rebels.

LEAD: AMONG the overlapping subdivisions of cabaret singing that include saloon, jazz, ''legit'' theatrical, actor-singer, and pop-rock approaches, the ''art'' singer, who treats pop with the gravity of serious concert fare, may be the rarest breed.

LEAD: TWENTY-EIGHT furniture artists were invited to ''make what they like to make'' for the Early Spring Show now at the Pritam & Eames Gallery in East Hampton, L.I. There were no functional requirements or an imposed theme. ''We really didn't know what we were going to get,'' said Bebe Johnson, one of the gallery owners.

LEAD: For several years Frank J. Gaffney Jr. has been known as a protege of Richard N. Perle, the hard-charging and outspoken Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Policy. Now the 33-year old Mr. Gaffney is in line to succeed Mr. Perle, who is leaving the Reagan Administration later this spring to write a novel and join the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative-leaning research group in the capital.

LEAD: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, said yesterday that he had discussed ''career opportunities for me'' at a White House meeting last week, but had decided to remain in New York to continue several investigations.
LEAD: Democrats pushed a $1 trillion 1988 budget through the House Budget Committee today but the Senate Budget Committee later defeated a similar measure proposed by its Democratic chairman.

LEAD: GARY WOLF, who played a program of works by Beethoven, Franck, Barber, Brahms and Samuel Adler at Weill Recital Hall Monday night, is a sensitive and musical pianist. He planned his program intelligently (muffling the notoriously resonant acoustics of the hall, for example, by pushing the piano into a far corner of the stage) and, for the most part, proved a careful executant as well.

LEAD: Last week, while a judge in New Jersey weighed his decision in the Baby M case, Noel P. Keane received an anxious telephone call from an infertile woman awaiting the birth of a child by a surrogate mother.

LEAD: Prices of silver and platinum futures rose yesterday as more banks raised their prime lending rates. But gold did not benefit from the renewed investor interest in precious metals. Gold closed unchanged, largely because the dollar was somewhat firmer and thus tended to dampen inflationary expectations.

LEAD: THE membership of the American Association of Retired Persons is 40 percent Republican, 40 percent Democrat and 20 percent independent, the organization says. To some critics, the diversity prevents the group from engaging in aggressive advocacy.
LEAD: High school dropout rates declined in the 1970's and early 1980's, a report by the Census Bureau indicates.

LEAD: The millions who throng Manhattan Island every day make it a singular world market where anyone with the cash or credit can buy Korean ginseng, Greek pumice, Long Island sand, Turkish carpets and Chinese talking bears (with batteries).

LEAD: FLORA WHITNEY MILLER chose art and furniture that expressed fantasy and wit for her duplex at 10 Gracie Square and her porticoed mansion in Old Westbury, L.I., her daughter, Flora Miller Biddle, recalled this week. LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In a surprise move, the National Basketball Association's expansion committee recommended yesterday Charlotte, N.C., as its first choice when it begins its three-team expansion process with the 1988-89 season.
LEAD: Israel's Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by the defense to disqualify the three-judge panel presiding over the trial of John Demjanjuk, who is accused of being a Nazi war criminal.

LEAD: ''A Place With the Pigs,'' now enjoying its world premiere engagement at the Yale Repertory Theater, is a surprise: an Athol Fugard play not set in South Africa. The play takes place instead, as its title indicates, with the pigs - or, as the program says, in ''a pigsty, in a small village, somewhere in the author's imagination.

LEAD: The pianist Peter Serkin will play his debut concert at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8. The program will include works by Bach, Beethoven, Toru Takemitsu, Olivier Messiaen and Stefan Wolpe. Tickets are $14 to $22.50. Information: 247-7800.

LEAD: House Democrats today assailed a Federal Communications Commission board proposal for a $1.50 increase in monthly telephone charges for households and small businesses, signaling a possible reduction.

LEAD: THERE is much that is admirable about Peter Gourfain's exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum. It is called ''Roundabout and Other Works,'' and it consists of 56 paintings, works on paper, ceramic pots and reliefs. The ambition is epic. Mr. Gourfain wants to include everything, inspire justice and transformation and compose a narrative on nothing less than the human condition.

LEAD: The Senate committee investigating the Iran-contra arms case voted today to compel the testimony of two clerical employees of Richard V. Secord, a principal figure in the affair, by giving them limited immunity from prosecution.

LEAD: Home Shopping Network Inc., the largest television shopping company, has been sued by two shareholders in Federal District Court in Tampa, Fla. The suit accuses the company of making false and misleading statements in public filings. The shareholders, Burton Rosenfeld and Victor P. Ganderson, are seeking class-action status.
LEAD: Pope John Paul II visited Gen. Augusto Pinochet, Chile's military ruler, in his palace today and a few hours later called for Chile to move toward democracy in the ''not distant future.''
LEAD: Andrei D. Sakharov, by vigorously supporting Mikhail S. Gorbachev, has caused some disillusionment among dissidents who once regarded him as a hero of almost mythical size.

LEAD: A secret report sent to President Reagan by his advisory panel on intelligence two years ago warned that the United States Embassy in Moscow was vulnerable to Soviet espionage, Government officials said today.

LEAD: The new owners of Lear Siegler Inc. announced yesterday that Norman A. Barkeley, the company's president, chairman and chief executive, had resigned, as had two other top officials, as part of the restructuring of the diversified automotive and manufacturing company.

LEAD: Bobby Meacham sat alone in front of his dressing stall today, tears welling and the thought of another demotion to the minor leagues sitting uneasily in his mind. A teammate, Dennis Rasmussen, came by to console him, but the hurt was too deep. Meacham had performed capably enough to win a job with the Yankees in their spring camp, yet he will not make the trip to Detroit Saturday afternoon for next the opener

LEAD: Fed by economic uncertainty and political confusion, a deep mood of pessimism appears to be taking hold of Brazil barely two years after the country emerged from more than two decades of military rule.

LEAD: IN several appearances since his New York debut in 1978, the Polish pianist Krystian Zimerman has proved himself a substantial artist whose formidable technique is enlisted in the service of a sensitive musical mind. His performance of the Brahms Piano Concerto No. 2 last evening with the New York Philharmonic, under the baton of his countryman Stanislaw

LEAD: In a break from the open style with which Phil Esposito has run the Rangers during the regular season, making himself and his players always available for scrutiny, Esposito will isolate the players for the first round of the playoffs, which begin next week. The Rangers will be in one hotel, the reporters in another.
LEAD: Anyone buying or selling a home may be affected by the Government's new effort to catch tax cheats.
LEAD: Mary Beth Whitehead vowed today to fight to overturn the court ruling that ended her maternal rights to Melissa Stern, the 1-year-old girl at the center of the Baby M custody fight.

LEAD: In an attempt to put pressure on Japan to resolve a trade dispute, Britain today identified at least 58 Japanese companies for possible expulsion within weeks and threatened to deny business licenses to Japanese applicants.
LEAD: Henri Cochet, one of the famed Four Musketeers of French tennis, died Wednesday night after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

LEAD: ''CLUB LIFE'' may well be the only film ever to set a funeral scene inside a disco, with mourners lined up along the railings, and the coffin and floral arrangements set up on the lighted dance floor. So it's original, anyhow. It also includes a gangland murder shot in a hall of mirrors, and a love scene shot on a transparent waterbed filled with fish.
LEAD: Bond prices resumed their downward spiral yesterday. Securities dealers said that tepid buying early in the day was overshadowed by large sell orders in the afternoon.

LEAD: Margaret Whiting, the Oak Room in the Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street (840-6800). ''It Might As Well Be Spring,'' the title of her recently published autobiography, is also the name of Margaret Whiting's new cabaret act, in which she interweaves her musical history with anecdotes about the hotel, which she is performing in for the first time.

LEAD: Sonny Rollins, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Encounters with Sonny Rollins, the reigning master of the tenor saxophone, can be positively transcendent. They can also be frustrating, because Mr. Rollins is one of those rare improvisers who play directly on the inspiration of the moment, and don't keep a ready fund of cliches handy for times when inspiration is in short supply.

LEAD: The backlog of unprocessed Federal tax returns is 18 percent lower than at this time a year ago, indicating a shorter wait for refunds, the Internal Revenue Service said today. Through last Friday, 52.8 million couples and individuals had filed returns, down from the 54 million received during the corresponding period last year.

LEAD: International A3-8 Andrei D. Sakharov's strong support of the policies of Mikhail S. Gorbachev has caused some disillusionent among Soviet dissidents who had viewed him as a hero of almost mythical proportions. Page A1

LEAD: For a record-breaking marathon swimmer who has conquered the 31-mile-wide English Channel and once spent 12 1/2 hours covering the 20 miles across the Cook Strait of New Zealand, Lynne Cox wouldn't seem much challenged by a piddling couple of miles. But the 2.7-mile island-to-island course she has set for herself this August is across the Bering Strait between Alaska and the Soviet Union, and if the 30-year-old Californian makes it, she'll be the only person known to have done so, for a good reason: At its warmest, the

LEAD: The Citizens Committee for the Right to Keep and Bear Arms has named it ''Moynihan's Monstrosity.'' It is a bill drafted by New York's Democratic Senator, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, to bar the manufacture and importation of .25- and .32-caliber ammunition as an indirect way to restrict the use of millions of pistols privately owned by

LEAD: As April arrives, so does the urge to clean up the bicycle for another season of riding. This weekend, Country Cycling Tours will offer its first guided day trips of the season. Tomorrow, the group will tour the horse farm country of New Jersey. On Sunday, the route will be along the North Shore of Long Island.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: If Alderman Wallace Davis Jr. wins re-election here Tuesday, supporters of the West Side officeholder will have to celebrate without him. Mr. Davis is in jail. And Clifford P. Kelley, a South Side Alderman seeking another term on the City Council, awaits a verdict from the courts as well as from the voters.
LEAD: Troy Loney scored two goals to help the Pittsburgh Penguins defeat the Devils, 6-2, tonight and assure themselves of beating the Devils out of fifth place in the Patrick Division.

LEAD: Merce Cunningham and his company will be the guests of honor at a gala champagne reception for the benefit of the Lehman College Art Gallery tomorrow following a performance starting at 8 P.M. by the company at Lehman Center for the Performing Arts. An ''Event,'' created by Mr. Cunningham, will be presented at the performance and the reception will take place at the art gallery on the Lehman College campus, Bedford Park Boulevard West and Goulden Avenue, the Bronx.
LEAD: Companies
LEAD: The Devils are planning to move heir top minor league affiliate from Portland, Me., to Utica, N.Y., John McMullen, the owner of the Devils, said yesterday.

LEAD: THE walking season is suddenly upon us, and all roads lead to the biggest show in town: New York City itself. Walking tours of the city - which have become a year-round institution, with determined strollers slogging through the slushiest streets - are suddenly in full bloom. There are more than a half dozen of them scheduled this weekend alone and the pace will continue through early autumn.

LEAD: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants was ''worried'' after the Super Bowl, he admitted yesterday. ''I was worried about signing all the coaches,'' he said. ''All the assistants' contracts were up after the season.'' But all have re-signed and talks are going on regarding an extension of the remaining two years of Parcells's contract.

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 380 money market mutual funds decreased $832.5 million, to $235.4 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 91 institutional funds were down $341.4 million, to $65.17 billion. Assets of the 197 general purpose funds were up $1.1 billion, to $63.21 billion.
LEAD: MOVIES like Paul Mayersberg's ''Captive'' are as rare as peacocks' teeth, and even more precious.

LEAD: There may be votes in Iowa and New Hampshire but there's gold in New York, and that's why Democratic and Republican presidential candidates are shuttling in and out of New York a year before the state's presidential primaries.
LEAD: Dr. David Adler, a physicist who dealt with the nature and properties of solid matter, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 51 years old.

LEAD: Dealers who want to sell the new generation of I.B.M. personal computers - which the company says will be the mainstay of corporate America for the next decade - must take an advanced, expensive training course, I.B.M. officials said today.

LEAD: Personnel records for the entire New York City Council staff were subpoenaed yesterday as part of the Manhattan District Attorney's investigation of state legislative hiring practices, a Council spokesman said last night.

LEAD: ''IMPRESSIONIST AND POST-IMPRESSIONIST MASTERPIECES: The Courtauld Collection,'' now at the Metropolitan Museum of Art through June 21, is an anthology of 48 paintings by Manet, Cezanne, Monet, Degas, Renoir, Gauguin, van Gogh, Seurat and others. Even in the Met, which is not short of paintings of that kind and date, some of the Courtauld pictures make a spectacular effect.

LEAD: Dwight Gooden flew to New York today and entered a drug rehabilitation clinic, where his use of cocaine will be measured and treated. But, from the front office to the recesses of the Mets' locker room, his employers and teammates insisted that they had neither known nor suspected that he had ever used drugs.

LEAD: The General Public Utilities Corporation declared a dividend yesterday for the first time since 1979, when it sustained severe financial difficulties following the accident at its Three Mile Island nuclear power plant.

LEAD: An American lawyer who has been linked to the Jonathan Jay Pollard spy case said today that he had been a legal adviser to the Israeli Defense Ministry and that Israel had refused to allow him to be questioned in the United States.

LEAD: Legislators from New England apparently think the greenest thoughts. An analysis of votes on key environmental legislation by the League of Conservation Voters found that the delegations from the New England states had the highest percentage of ''right'' votes from an environmentalist perspective.

LEAD: Most major banks have increased their prime lending rate to 7 3/4 percent from 7 1/2 percent, completing a move that started Tuesday. The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company was among the last major banks in New York to adopt the higher rate.

LEAD: ''LETHAL WEAPON,'' the story of two Los Angeles policemen who try to break open a drug-smuggling ring, is a runaway hit. By the end of last weekend, the film, which opened on March 6, had grossed nearly $33.6 million, and had been No. 1 in the country for three weeks in a row. What's more, it actually did better in its second weekend than its first, grossing $7.1 million from 1,256 theaters the second weekend after grossing $6.8 million from the same number of theaters in the first.

LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today overrode President Reagan's veto of the highway bill: FOR OVERRIDING VETO - 67 Democrats - 54 Adams, Wash. Baucus, Mont.; Bentsen, Tex. Biden, Del. Bingaman, N.M. Boren, Okla. Bradley, N.J. Breaux, La. Bumpers, Ark.

LEAD: John W. Rockefeller Jr., a consulting engineer who perfected and manufactured the mainspring of the Norden bombsight used in Allied fighter planes in World War II, died Tuesday at the Green Grove Health Care Center in Neptune, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in Asbury Park, N.J.

LEAD: Four days after Sandy Lyle of Surrey, England, won the $1 million Tournament Players Championship on the men's PGA Tour, another young golfer from Surrey, Laura Davies, became the surprise first-round leader in the $500,000 L.P.G.A. Nabisco Dinah Shore event. Davies, a 23-year-old, 5-foot-10-inch player who hits as long a ball as anyone on the L.P.G.A.

LEAD: ON first impression it looked a little too swanky to be taken seriously as a pasta house, what with all that brass and glass and movie-star murals and a tinkling waterfall in the dining room. Then again, the menu seemed inviting, and a wind current of garlic and oregano grabbed me by the scruff of the neck and tugged me inside, so

LEAD: ON the far reaches of West 57th Street, a line snakes into the Unitel Video studio. Once inside, the people clamber to their seats, arced around a tiny stage that looks like a cross between a doctor's office and a living room. Cameramen mill about as first the stage manager, then the producer and finally the co-host warm up the audience with the sort of banter that can be heard only in that province of videoland known as studio-audience television.

LEAD: The last round of a Swiss Team Championship almost invariably produces tension. Several teams are likely to have a chance of victory, and the players know it is vital to bid thoughtfully and concentrate in the play.

LEAD: Reports on Tuesday of a New York Times/CBS News Poll on evangelical ministers and television programs misstated the number of people interviewed. The total was 1,392, not 1,394, and those who said they never watched evangelical ministers totaled 887, not 889. In the accompanying article about Presidential preferences based on the same poll, percentages were misstated for Senator Albert Gore and Representative Richard A.

LEAD: New York's old guard joined forces with the new on Wednesday night, and for $750 a ticket the oldeau and the nouveau got the chance to rub elegant elbows with the city's spiffed-up literary world. The result, at the Metropolitan Club, was a jam-packed, celebrity-studded event at which even the most blase eyes opened wide in amazement.

LEAD: A painting once attributed to ''Workshop of Titian'' that is now attributed to the Venetian master himself. An X-ray, bottom, confirmed the authorship and showed that the painting originally had an angel at the left, which was replaced by dense shrubbery and a finch. Page C28.
LEAD: The State Supreme Court ruled today that water companies could be sued for failing to provide adequate water pressure for fighting fires.

LEAD: The Federal district judge who ordered the Boston schools desegregated and took control of them for nearly a decade said today that the Reagan Administration was mistaken in its emphasis on judicial restraint.
LEAD: The investor Paul A. Bilzerian, seeking to take over the Pay N Pak Stores hardware chain, offered to buy all shares that he does not control for $19 each, or about $171 million.

LEAD: At 9:23 tonight, in a party tent poised somewhere between romance and avarice, an auctioneer hammered out the sale of the first of the costly baubles that were scattered as love tokens across the lives of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor.

LEAD: Brazil's Finance Minister, Dilson Funaro, said today that the Government hopes to raise $20 billion in new foreign credits over the next five years despite its suspension of some interest payments to banks.

LEAD: Ray Miller, a former featherweight boxer and later a referee with the New York State Boxing Commission, died Tuesday. He had been suffering from lung cancer for some time, his wife said. He was 82 years old.

LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration today barred its own medical institute from conducting alcohol and drug tests after aviation accidents. It said it had asked the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology to conduct a ''thorough and independent assessment'' of the F.A.A. institute's procedures.

LEAD: Yogi Berra, in a forthcoming television commercial for Miller Lite: ''It's got a third less calories than I probably thought it didn't have, and it's less filling than it would have been if it was more filling than they didn't want it to be.''

LEAD: CONTRIVED mystery, the kind that saves skins or enhances images, is a commonplace. The real thing, on the other hand, is a rarity, and never more so than in the realm of contemporary art. Raoul Hague qualifies if only as a sculptor who, at the age of 82, has but seven solo shows to his credit and who, it seems, has never taught.
LEAD: They told Ronald Reagan not to do it, but he went ahead anyway.
LEAD: By tomorrow evening, there should finally be some clear favorites for the 113th Kentucky Derby May 2, because almost every leading contender is making a key start tomorrow afternoon.
LEAD: The Senate, with not a vote to spare, overrode President Reagan's veto of the highway bill today despite an extraordinary personal appeal by the President at the Capitol.

LEAD: AFTER cleaning and restoration at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and exhaustive research by a Met curator, a large painting attributed simply to ''Workshop of Titian'' is now attributed to the great Venetian master himself.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission will once again consider whether to recommend legislation to eliminate the practice known as ''greenmail,'' according to Commissioner Charles C. Cox. Greenmail is the repurchase of shares, at a premium, from unwanted suitors, in order to head off hostile takeovers.
LEAD: When boxing champions step into the gym, more often than not they are preceded by large entourages.
LEAD: To the Editor:
Buddy Rich, a hot-tempered musician who drummed his way through vaudeville shows and big bands, died yesterday at UCLA Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 69 years old.

LEAD: In the opening segment of ''Frank Dell's St. Antony,'' the newest performance piece by the Wooster Group, images of naked flesh and spiritual obsession interact in a provocative collage of music, video and dramatic monologue. Wearing sunglasses and a bathrobe, the actor Ron Vawter stands beneath video monitors on which members of the company are shown lounging around in the nude and engaged in desultory conversation.

LEAD: As a result of an agreement with the estate of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., a historian at Stanford University is editing the complete papers of the civil-rights leader, and the University of California Press will publish them in 12 volumes over the next 15 years.

LEAD: On April 12, automobile tolls on the three Hudson River crossings into Manhattan will rise, to $3 from $2, and PATH fares will increase, to $1 from 75 cents, the Port Authority announced yesterday.
LEAD: THE decision of Citibank to raise its prime rate of interest by one-quarter of a point, to 7 3/4 percent - a move quickly followed by other major banks - took Wall Street by surprise.

LEAD: Outlook for Times Sq. City and state officials are taking steps to save the $2 billion Times Square redevelopment project from possible collapse. Page B1. Windsor Jewels Auctioned Jewels of the Duchess of Windsor were auctioned in Geneva for $33.5 million. This 31-carat diamond ring fetched $3.15 million.

LEAD: Intelligence information provided by the United States and France is helping the Chadian Army in its successful campaign against Libyan forces in the northern part of the country, according to senior Chadian officials in Ndjamena, the capital.

LEAD: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, parent of the world's largest brewer, said it was under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a Federal grand jury over reports that some executives had received improper payments.

LEAD: Because of a transmission error, an article in some copies yesterday about the indictment of former Borough President Stanley Simon of the Bronx carried an incorrect quotation from Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan. Speaking about corruption, he said, ''It is going to take more than the one or two convictions that have taken place so far to change these people and the way they operate.

LEAD: As officials struggled to come up with a state budget, already two days late, Governor Cuomo acknowledged today that his administration was not part of key negotiations and that the Legislature was putting together a fiscal plan without him.
LEAD: The Senate unanimously passed a bill today authorizing the Federal Government to pay bonuses to states that move long-term welfare recipients into jobs in private industry.

LEAD: Two members of a prominent Maryland political family were indicted today by a Federal grand jury in Baltimore in connection with the investigation of the Wedtech Corporation, a South Bronx military contractor.

LEAD: President Reagan has nominated Maj. Gen. Charles R. Hamm for a promotion and new assignment as superintendent of the Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs, the Defense Department said today. If the nomination is confirmed by the Senate, General Hamm would receive his third star and replace Lieut. Ge,.

LEAD: Friday JUILLIARD CONCERTS The Juilliard School will present a series of three free concerts in its first ''New Music Weekend.'' The series is entitled ''Then and Now,'' and features music by 20th-century pioneers and new composers, Tonight at 8, works by Charles Ives, Roger Sessions, Vincent Persichetti and Milton Babbitt will be played at Alice Tully Hall under the direction of Paul Zukofsky.

LEAD: WITH young (under 30) top executives and a budget of $150 million in place, Fox Broadcasting Company is taking its first wobbly steps this Sunday toward what its hopes will be a fourth commercial network in prime time. Two half-hour series are being unveiled: ''Married. . . With Children'' at 7 P.M., and ''The Tracey Ullman Show'' at 7:30.

LEAD: The New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players will present a double bill containing new productions of ''Trial by Jury'' and ''The Sorcerer'' tonight at 8, Saturday at 3 and 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Symphony Space, 95th Street and Broadway. Tickets are $15 to $25; information: 864-5400.
LEAD: Seven years ago a Miami office worker had an affair with a bisexual man. She recalls that his confusion about sexual orientation was one of the things that made her feel tender toward him.

LEAD: The dollar skidded again this week, sending stocks and bonds into a brief but worrisome nosedive. Talk persists of a trans-Pacific ''trade war'' over microchips and broken promises. Now, unexpectedly, banks have raised their prime loan rates. All a little unnerving. The events showed, once again, the calamities that could lie ahead unless Washington and Tokyo stop tinkering and testing each other and address the underlying problems.

LEAD: THE rain splattering the windowpanes added some notes Handel never wrote, but the New York Harp Ensemble played on and Eva Marton lifted her glorious voice above it all at Monday night's musicale in Jenifer and George Lang's West Side apartment. Then the guests - who included Marion and Elie Wiesel, Renate Ponsold and Robert Motherwell, Dietlinde and Lorin Maazel, Shirley and Milton Glaser, Peter Jennings, Tom Margittai and Vera Stern - trooped in the rain to the Cafe des Artistes for a dinner celebrating the restaurant's 70th anniversary.
LEAD: Eastern Airlines pilots in uniform picketed the carrier's major terminals today to dramatize their charges that Eastern's new cost-cutting work policies could create unsafe flying conditions.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ARCHER'S, #1310 Palisade Avenue, Fort Lee (201-224-5652) - **(Nov. 30, 1986) Now that spring is officially here, areas outside the city seem to beckon; whether you're going to or coming from New Jersey, you might stop at this popular Italian restaurant in Fort Lee.

LEAD: Sandra Raye Gendel supervising placement of a canvas at 667 Madison Avenue. Ms. Gendel's work will be displayed in second-floor windows while the 25-story building is under construction. Works by Richard Leonard are being displayed in first-floor windows. The two artists were awarded commissions for the work, a total of 18 canvases, after being selected in a young artists' competition.

LEAD: Called the green berets of New York City's Department of Probation, members of the agency's 18-month-old Field Service Unit are breathing new life into an agency considered overwhelmed and ineffective by judges, prosecutors and many probation officers themselves.
LEAD: Textron Inc. is offering $150 million of 9 1/4 percent subordinated debentures due in 2017 at a price of 97 1/2 to yield 9.50 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

LEAD: MUTUAL fund sales charges were once relatively static affairs; a fund either levied a ''load'' - or front-end sales charge - or else it was no-load. But lately a number of management companies have put into effect strategies aimed at garnering a bigger share of the booming fund business.

LEAD: So many new homes are being built in suburban areas near New York City that many municipalities are finding they are unable to keep up with the added demand put on their waste treatment facilities and sewage systems.
LEAD: Two Rikers Island inmates were shot and slightly wounded Wednesday night, and the authorities have not determined who used the .25-caliber automatic handgun found nearby.

LEAD: The Chemical New York Corporation's debt ratings were reduced yesterday by Moody's, shortly before the bank holding company announced that it was no longer accruing interest on more than $1 billion of loans to Brazil.
LEAD: Lots of money is spent fighting over a few children in our society - Baby M, Baby Jane Doe, the sons and daughters in divorce custody wars.

LEAD: A recent proposal from the Manhattan Borough President, calling for a vast expansion in the number of apartments the city rehabilitates for the homeless, ''makes no sense,'' Mayor Koch said yesterday.

LEAD: The Brooklyn Philharmonic, under the direction of Lukas Foss, will play the New York premiere performances of Oliver Knussen's ''Music for a Puppet Court'' tonight and tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 2 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The program will also include Samuel Barber's Violin Concerto, played by Elmar Oliveira, and Symphony No.
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation's competitors in the personal computer industry, who had been bracing for the worst, breathed a slight sigh of relief today.

LEAD: The Federal judicial panel that administers the law on special prosecutors ruled today that it did not have the authority to broaden the scope of a special investigation after the Attorney General refused to do so.
LEAD: A Federal grand jury indicted two more executives of Paine Webber Group Inc. yesterday in connection with what was characterized as a $700,000 money-laundering scheme. The executives - Joseph

LEAD: The Republican Presidential landscape for 1988 was altered again today as former Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada prepared to form an committee to look into whether he should run and Donald Rumsfeld announced that he would not be a candidate.
LEAD: Michael Lytle will play a solo concert of new music for clarinet today at 9 and 10:30 P.M. at the Spare Room, 107 Morton Street (807-6267). Admission is $3.

LEAD: ''THE traditional text of rock lyrics is adolescent love, period,'' said Robert Sietsema of the New York rock band Mofungo. ''We're not adolescents anymore, and we're not so interested in adolescent love, either. We read the paper and watch the news and when we get together to rehearse, we often start by discussing something we've read or seen.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Glenn Hoffman, a seven-year veteran who missed most of the 1986 season with a cardiac problem, was cut by the Boston Red Sox yesterday in what Manager John McNamara called ''one of the toughest decisions I've ever had to make.'' Hoffman, who was Boston's regular shortstop before his illness, Kevin Romine, an outfielder, and five rookies were cut as the Red Sox got down to 25 players.

LEAD: Six years after it began to make its personal computer as familiar in American offices as the filing cabinet, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced a new, far more powerful line of desktop machines designed to carry it into the 1990's.
LEAD: Patients arriving at the New York center where Dwight Gooden has been sent for help in coping with his drug problem are first interviewed about their dependency.

LEAD: Cigarette production last year dropped about 3 percent, to 643 billion cigarettes, an Agriculture Department report said. ''Domestic use fell, but exports rose,'' the department's Economic Research Service said Wednesday. ''U.S. smokers consumed 584 billion cigarettes in 1986, about 2 percent fewer than in 1985.
LEAD: ''I see myself as I saw myself 10 years ago. I still say what I think.'' - Andrei D. Sakharov. [ A1:1. ]

LEAD: BIBLIOMANIA is a mental and emotional disorder that is chronic, progressive, incurable and entirely benign. Those suffering from this delightful affliction, which may or may not cost a bundle to treat, are urged to seek emergency relief at the New York Antiquarian Book Fair. It opened last night and the rare-book dealers on duty will administer first aid to all bibliomaniacs through tomorrow.

LEAD: N.B.A. Pistons 119, Pacers 73: Vinnie Johnson scored 25 points and Rick Mahorn and John Salley added 17 each last night to lead Detroit to victory at home over Indiana. The margin was the greatest ever for the Pistons. The Pistons led by as many as 49 points, 115-66, while winning for the third time in their last four games.

LEAD: Bob McAdoo, former National Basketball Association scoring champion, scored 15 of his 21 points in the second half today as Tracer Milan won the European Champions Cup by edging Maccabi Tel Aviv of Israel, 71-69, in the final.

LEAD: The Federal shutdown of the Peach Bottom Atomic Power Station here illustrates a mounting problem for the nuclear power industry: the people who work in the plants are often less reliable than the technology.
LEAD: Cosmetics are glamorous, but not necessarily on Wall Street.

LEAD: Faced with the possible collapse of the $2 billion Times Square redevelopment project, New York City and state officials have renegotiated one portion of the plan and have opened new talks with developers in an effort to save the others.

LEAD: After months of uncertainty and tension, Canada and the United States are within reach of a ''historic'' trade agreement that would eliminate most tariff and non-tariff barriers between the two nations over 10 to 15 years, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney has concluded.
LEAD: A Long Island man facing deportation to the Soviet Union as a war criminal, won a delay yesterday until at least Monday so that his lawyers could go to the United States Supreme Court.

LEAD: Of all the things to be said of Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms this is one of the most telling: He has made his country exciting. It is true, of course, that what would be unworthy of note in Paris, Rio or Tokyo is stunning when coming from Moscow. Soviet life has been that sluggish. Yet this is more than mere stirring from the dormant.

LEAD: Visitors to the Museum of Modern Art's sculpture garden getting into the spirit of the setting yesterday as they enjoyed the warming rays of a fleeting sun. LEAD: Andy Rooney, the ''60 Minutes'' commentator who has had a running dispute with CBS management over cutbacks and a writers' strike at CBS News, said last night that he would quit CBS if the strike is not soon resolved.

LEAD: Philip Colleck, an antiques dealer in Manhattan and London, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 73 years old.

LEAD: The Mets began the painful task of regrouping their spirits and their pitching today, and started by naming Bob Ojeda to replace Dwight Gooden as their opening-day pitcher against the Pittsburgh Pirates next Tuesday in Shea Stadium.

LEAD: William J. Casey, former Director of Central Intelligence, promised in writing in June 1986 to notify the Senate Intelligence Committee of any secret United States arms sales, but failed to tell it about the clandestine weapons sales to Iran then under way, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has disclosed.

LEAD: Marvelous Marvin Hagler suffered his second legal setback of the week when a Federal appeals court today refused to stop the World Boxing Association from stripping him of its middleweight crown.

LEAD: The basement swimming pool at the Trinity School at 91st Street and Columbus Avenue in Manhattan is not exactly high technology. It is 25 yards long and six lanes wide. It is only 4 feet deep and the ceiling is only 12 feet high.

LEAD: A day after he said he almost certainly would remain as basketball coach at the University of New Orleans, Benny Dees was lured away for twice the money by his alma mater, the University of Wyoming. This was only Dees's second season as coach of the Privateers. But he led them to a 26-4 record, their first national ranking, 16th at the end of the season, and their first appearance in the N.C.A.A.

LEAD: A. Richard Turner has been named director of the New York Institute for the Humanities at New York University. An authority on Italian Renaissance painting, Mr. Turner, a former president of Grinnell College, was most recently the dean of the Faculty of Arts and Science at N.Y.U.
LEAD: The Mellon Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh said yesterday that it would report a first-quarter loss of between $55 million and $65 million, news that sent its stock plunging.

LEAD: President Reagan and the Indiana University basketball coach, Bobby Knight, traded compliments in the Rose Garden yesterday as the President welcomed the N.C.A.A. men's championship team to the White House one day after greeting the women's champions from the University of Tennessee. ''Critics aside, one thing is certain: Bobby cares deeply about his players on and off the court,'' the President said.

LEAD: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the middleweight champion, turned up in public today in a bright red cap modeled after the headgear worn by the French Foreign Legion, right down to the twin flaps hanging at the back of his shaven head.

LEAD: An appeals court has ruled that a condominium on the Upper East Side is 12 stories too tall and it may have to be partially dismantled unless a higher court grants relief. A lawyer for the developer said, meantime, that an appeal is planned.

LEAD: Smoke rising from the wreckage of grain silos after an explosion yesterday morning in Burlington. Five people were injured, one of them seriously, as the explosion blew the tops out of six 10-story silos in the 12-silo complex and damaged others at the Archer Daniels Midland elevator. The blast shattered windows for 25 blocks and forced the evacuation of downtown buildings as flames threatened an underground fuel tank.

LEAD: A few minutes after the lights go up on ''Return to the River,'' we know we are in for a consciousness-going-up session as Al Gilroy, a black attorney for an American oil company, arrives at the awareness that South Africa is his problem. The play's problem is that of many problem-plays: characters tend to become walking pamphlets and the stage becomes a lecture platform.
LEAD: The nation's unemployment rate edged downward to 6.5 percent in March but job growth slowed sharply, the Government reported today.

LEAD: Jane Elliott Berentson, managing editor of Corporate Finance magazine in New York, and Frederick Robert Bleakley, an assistant business editor of The New York Times, were married yesterday at the Municipal Building in Manhattan by William G. Thymius, the executive assistant to the city clerk.
LEAD: The stock market capped off a tumultuous week yesterday with a flourish, as the Dow Jones industrial average soared 69.89 points - its largest single-day advance ever.

LEAD: The Police Academy series seems to shoot for an ever younger crowd. The optimum viewer for ''Police Academy 4: Citizens on Patrol,'' which opened yesterday at the Criterion Center and other theaters, would be a 10-year-old boy. Even better, it would be a whole pack of them. That's not to say the film isn't funny; it means only that the sense of humor being addressed is very specific.

LEAD: Daily bombing raids by Libyan jets have destroyed or damaged half of the Soviet-made aircraft seized intact by Chadian troops when they captured the Libyan base of Wadi Dum two weeks ago, a French military officer said today.

LEAD: Steve Carlton, a starter throughout his 22 years in the major leagues, signed today with the Cleveland Indians and will become a middle-inning relief pitcher in his latest attempt to revive his career. ''We're gambling that he can fill a role for us,'' said Joe Klein, the Indians' vice president. ''He's healthy, and the point is, he can fall out of bed and pitch two innings.
LEAD: A tornado ripped the roofs off 16 greenhouses as it swept through a large nursery today, injuring an employee of the nursery, the authorities said.

LEAD: On their toes to anticipate an architectural drop shot, some Central Park tennis players talk of resisting replacement of their familiar tennis house with a new building. It is reasonable for New Yorkers to be suspicious of Central Park ''improvements''; many have turned out badly. But the present stuccoed tennis house, a midget Greek Revival anachronism set in the Victorian Gothic wonderland of Central Park, deserves demolition.

Reducing this maternal mortality rate - a goal recently, and commendably, set by the World Bank - depends heavily on birth control and health care services. Sadly, over the last three years the United States Government's commitment to this noble cause has continued to diminish.

LEAD: Gen. Augusto Pinochet rules Chile by default as well as by force. He is surrounded by opponents but they, unlike those who supplanted dictators in Argentina and the Philippines, have yet to transform themselves into a viable political opposition. Beyond the courage to speak out, these opponents need the wisdom to transcend division and establish a new pragmatic consensus.

His synagogue, Temple Beth Israel, was bombed in September and his home two months later.

LEAD: An investor group led by Wagner & Brown of Texas and AFG Industries of California tentatively sweetened its takeover bid for Gencorp Inc. yesterday by $225 million, raising its offer to $2.46 billion.

LEAD: A Federal grand jury in Arkansas that has been investigating neo-Nazi terrorist activity for several months appears ready to issue indictments against right-wing extremist leaders, according to officials with knowledge of the investigation. The charges are said to include possible counts of sedition, The grand jury inquiry, in Fort Smith, Ark., as well as others in Spokane, Wash., and Denver, grew out of earlier Federal investigations that, in Seattle in early 1986, led to the conviction of 10 members of a violent anti-Semitic group calling itself the Order.

LEAD: Nearly 23 million gallons of virtually raw sewage will flow into San Francisco Bay each day for the next week because of a breakdown at a treatment plant, officials say. LEAD: A pinpoint hole in a charred chunk of a failed satellite rocket was strong evidence the rocket was hit by lightning before it broke apart last week, the head of an investigation team said today.

LEAD: Air Atlanta, the three-year-old airline that was the brainchild of a black businessman, Michael R. Hollis, filed for protection from its creditors today under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. All of its flights were grounded immediately, and its workers were laid off.

LEAD: Bob Stanley, returning to a starting role after six years in the Boston bullpen, was named to start for the Red Sox in their season opener at Milwaukee. Stanley was picked to replace Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, who has a sore pitching shoulder. Contract negotiations continued, meanwhile, with Roger Clemens, the team's star right-hander.
LEAD: New tests on drinking-water wells near the Texas Eastern Gas Pipeline in West Amwell, N.J., have found no detectable traces of PCB's, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency reported today.

LEAD: Safeway Stores Inc., the largest supermarket chain in the country, said today that it would pull out of the northern Texas market, either closing or selling the 141 stores in its Dallas division by April 24.

LEAD: If the prospect of seeing seven new one-act plays over two evenings seems daunting, here's a suggestion: Choose Evening A of the Class One Acts annual festival, dally over dinner and get to the Nat Horne Theater at intermission, about 9:30. You'll be in time for ''Beirut,'' Alan Bowne's stunner about love in the plague years.

LEAD: The National Basketball Association playoff hopes of the Seattle SuperSonics took a severe blow Thursday night when Alton Lister, the 7-foot center who is the team's top rebounder, shot-blocker and fourth-leading scorer, suffered a fractured right foot in a 117-114 loss to the Los Angeles Lakers. After making a layup late in the first half, he left the game with what was believed to be a sprained ankle.

LEAD: ON THE AFTERNOON OF MARCH 26, Robert Colangelo, chief of detectives of the New York City Police Department, was in his office, posing for a celebratory photograph with a detachment of his men. ''Let's put up a sign,'' shouted a jubilant Colangelo. '' 'Westies - R.I.P.' Make it as big as you can!''

LEAD: The best thing the Mets can do for Dwight Gooden is hope and pray he finds the answers to why he chose to self-destruct just before the baseball season, which has been the core of his identity. The next best thing the Mets can do for him is go on without him.
LEAD: A plan to clean up heavily polluted Flushing Bay in Queens is threatening to divide New York City environmental and parks officials.
LEAD: A commitment to visit all Chileans brought Pope John Paul II today to the southernmost city in the world, this cold and windy little place on the very tip of the American mainland.

LEAD: THE FUTURE OF IMMORTALITY: And Other Essays for a Nuclear Age. By Robert Jay Lifton. (Basic, $21.95.) The chief difference, presumably, would be that the dancers were predominantly black rather than white.

But he said he found time on weekends and at 5 o'clock most mornings in the last nine months to ''scratch out'' his latest composition, Symphony No. 5, which was commissioned by the Greater Bridgeport Symphony.

''That was a very realistic price,'' Ms. Hyman said, ''although I figured I might let it go for a little less.

LEAD: We tend to think of Vladimir Nabokov as elegant and aloof, but in Paris in the 1930's he was a struggling young writer like so many others. V. S. Yanovsky, another Russian emigre writer, describes Nabokov in in his memoir ''Elysian Fields'' (Northern Illinois University).

LEAD: Question: I own shares in a co-op in New Jersey. When the building was converted in 1981 the sponsor took back a $2.5 million mortgage for 10 years at 11 percent interest, which he subsequently sold to Dollar Dry Dock Savings Bank of New York. The mortgage calls for a prepayment penalty of 5 percent up to the fourth year and subsequent penalties which would decline by 0.5 percent annually.

Alice Miskimin was quoted in paraphrase as stating that female lawyers were not admitted to membership in the New York State Bar Association until the 1930's. That information was not correct.

After all, 3,400 years after the Exodus of the Jews from Egypt, the seder, which starts April 13, is being celebrated in much the original way.

LEAD: IN Pleasantville, it has long been the custom around Christmas for villagers to gather at the gazebo near the railroad station to sing carols. A few years ago, a woman who was the guest of a local family watched as the man leading the singing paused to ask who had been there before.

LEAD: FOR nearly five years, according to the authorities, William Depperman drove New York City sanitation inspectors up a wall.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH a portable electric drill is probably the first power tool most do-it-yourselfers acquire, and it is one power tool that is found in almost every home nowadays, many homeowners still do not know how to get maximum use out of these tools.

LEAD: SOME analysts were afraid that last week's news about real estate investment trusts was, to quote Yogi Berra, like deja vu all over again. Of the seven biggest quarterly decliners on the New York Stock Exchange, three were realty trusts. A dozen years ago, such trusts littered the losers' lists on the major exchanges, as the industry was plagued with scores of bankruptcies and other problems.

LEAD: AT THE first-ever Kosher Food and Life Expo at the Jacob Javits Convention Center last month, more than 50,000 people eagerly noshed their way through everything from gefilte fish to kosher tacos. For the plain old hungry folks in the crowd, the day represented great fun. But to Irving Silverman, the show's ebullient organizer, and to the food industry executives milling about, the huge turnout branded kosher food as a blockbuster sales item.

LEAD: Margaret Thatcher and Mikhail S. Gorbachev got together again last week, with mutually beneficial results. The British Prime Minister flew home after five days in Moscow, telling reporters she ''would implicitly accept'' the word of the Soviet leader.

LEAD: In the garage on East Elm Street in the Hillsborough section of Tampa, the red Porsche and silver Mercedes stand as the symbols of success. In the modest one-story house, the agonized looks, the 13-month-old baby and the missing father stand as the symbols of failure.

LEAD: IN THE wake of sex-discrimination charges against Ramapo College and Rutgers University by female faculty members, many college officials in the state are looking more closely at their institutions' hiring, promotion and tenure procedures.

LEAD: The American Embassy in Moscow contains a chamber specially secured against Soviet eavesdropping. But even this bug-proof bubble may not be secure enough for use by Secretary of State Shultz on his forthcoming visit to Moscow. The Marine guards who let the K.G.B. roam the embassy may have compromised almost everything done there.

LEAD: RENEWED by a change in mechanics, Steve Carlton said yesterday he signed with the Cleveland Indians because ''I've got two or three more years, absolutely.'' Carlton, the only pitcher to win the Cy Young Award four times, insisted he is far from over the hill at age 42.

LEAD: An explosion ripped through a natural gas storage terminal here today, sending flames high into air and forcing evacuation of about 75 homes within 2 1/2 miles, the authorities said. No injuries were reported. Civil defense officials said they were contemplating expanding the evacuation area fearing further explosions at the site, a Mid America Pipe Line Company facility here.
LEAD: I would like to respond to Stan Lipton's comments in ''Library Elections: Consolidate Them'' [ Opinion Page, March 8 ] .

LEAD: The adrenal hormone norepinephrine and the neurotransmitter dopamine are chemically very similar. And so scientists have wondered if they could cure Parkinson's disease, a neurological disorder thought to be caused by a dopamine deficiency, by transplanting tissue from the adrenal glands into the brain.

LEAD: AS the news about Dwight Gooden spread the other afternoon, the same things were being said all over, and it is hard to disagree with any of them. Yes, of course, the poor guy merits sympathy. But, damn right, no one put a gun to his head! Hey, on the other hand, he's still just a kid - 22! -and this is the kind of mistake kids make.
LEAD: ROBINS and crocuses spell spring for many. But for serious eaters on Long Island and elsewhere, asparagus symbolizes spring.

LEAD: FROM the Pretenders who released their first album in 1980, only one original member remains - Chrissie Hynde, the band's leader and singer. The new Pretenders haven't spurred Ms. Hynde to write songs as unconventional and feisty as her older material. But on Tuesday at Radio City Music Hall, opening a four-night stand, the band played the daylights out of all its songs; it has the force and tunefulness of the old Pretenders at their best.
