LEAD: The Week in Business column last Sunday incorrectly described how the proceeds from the sale of 40 percent of Shearson Lehman Brothers, to Nippon Life and the public, would be distributed. Shearson is expected to receive about $600 million in new capital. American Express, Shearson's parent, is expected to receive about $650 million from the sale of shares to the public.

LEAD: A CLERK falls asleep and dreams of Napoleon. ''Napoleon Nightdreams,'' at the McCarter Theatre here, is the depiction of that dream by the playwright James McLure and the director Nagle Jackson.

LEAD: A newspaper reporter need not disclose his confidential sources for an article about possible legal violations in a Nevada gambling casino owned in part by former Senator Paul Laxalt, a Federal judge has ruled.

LEAD: HE'S better known for his success on the football field, but Joe Paterno, the Penn State coach, has always had a keen interest in education, so it should come as no surprise that his latest honor comes from the Friends of Libraries USA. It gave him a life membership and a plaque at a ceremony in Philadelphia on Friday.

LEAD: The fact that people will line up for tickets to this fight continues to amaze me. Hagler has not lost in 10 years. He has beaten every style of fighter put before him. He is an excellent boxer who can also take you out with one punch from either hand. He has a granite chin. He is a natural middleweight.
LEAD: THE CHILDREN AT SANTA CLARA By Elizabeth Marek. 177 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $16.95.
LEAD: For the last six years, ever since this capital won the right to stage the 1988 Summer Olympics, the Games have loomed as South Korea's equivalent to the Promised Land.

LEAD: A March 1 article about the town of Lebanon [ ''Book Tells of the Life of a Town'' ] stated that the Jonathan Trumbull House was maintained by the Lebanon Historical Society. In fact, the Trumbull House, on the green, is owned and maintained by the Connecticut Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution as a museum.
LEAD: Stress comes from many sources: tight travel schedules, competitive sports and even elementary school, say participants in a new stress management course for children 5 to 12 years old.

LEAD: The City University of New York Law School, in its admissions brochure, says it has a responsibility to create a campus environment ''that is more diversified and more representative of the full range of peoples that make up New York City and the United States.''

LEAD: Robin Diane Gunty, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard D. Gunty of Portland, Me., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. Joel Mark Evans, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Evans of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Arnold Turetsky performed the ceremony at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel in New York.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Evelyn Sklar of Fort Lee, N.J., of the engagement of her daughter, Amy Fern Sklar, to Ronald Bruce Kremnitzer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Kremnitzer of New York. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: The legal battle over Baby M that was decided this week in a New Jersey courtroom has focused attention on a widening gap between the number of infertile American couples who want children and the number of babies available for adoption.

LEAD: Jennifer Pulitzer Feldman, the daughter of Judge and Mrs. Martin Leach-Cross Feldman of New Orleans, and Steven Paul Lund, a son of Virginia Lund Callaway of Ridgewood, N.J., and the late Paul Martin Lund, were married last night. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Murray Blackman at the home of the bride's parents.

LEAD: The good news about infamous Terminal B at Newark International Airport is that gigantic Terminal C is on the way. The bad news is that the New York hub of Continental Airlines, still struggling to digest the People Express whale, will continue to be Terminal B during the height of this year's travel season.
LEAD: ''IS HOUSING available? A 200-bed dormitory is planned, with opening tentatively set for the fall of 1987.''
LEAD: Most American women are vulnerable to sex discrimination in schools and universities, according to a report by the National Organization for Women.

LEAD: To the Editor: James V. Risser's article on Sydney and its Opera House (Travel, Feb. 1) brought back fond memories of similar experiences we enjoyed in July 1984. Like Mr. Risser, we toured the Opera House, ate at the Bennelong Restaurant and took the ferry to Manly and back.

LEAD: A pro-Government newspaper reported today that the Government is planning to charge the former leader of the liberal white opposition with possessing a publication of the outlawed African National Congress.

LEAD: Mary Frances Conserva and Kenneth Robert Barre, the manager of business affairs and a senior art director, respectively, for Ally & Gargano/MCA Advertising in New York, were married yesterday at St. Cassian's Roman Catholic Church in Upper Montclair, N.J. MSGR. Vincent E. Puma performed the ceremony.

LEAD: WILHELMINA HOLLIDAY, touring a museum in Vienna years ago with her husband, was taken with the work of Clara Peeters. Returning to the United States, she attempted to find out more about Peeters. What she found was not only that Peeters was absent from H. W. Janson's ''History of Art,'' but that no other woman artist was included either.
LEAD: Although President Chun Doo Hwan says he will step down next February, it is generally assumed that he wants to designate his successor.

LEAD: ''He'll do fine in that place for 30 days. But what's going to happen when he comes out and visits Los Angeles, Chicago, St. Louis and all those places? That's what I'm worried about. Can he handle that?''
LEAD: A homeless man was killed yesterday when he was pushed in front of a subway train at the Times Square Station, the Transit Authority police said.
LEAD: NOW that many hospitals in Connecticut no longer find it profitable to treat patients on a day-to-day basis, they are seeking ways to make themselves more efficient and cost-effective.

LEAD: THE recent proposal by the Metropolitan Club to sell the air rights over its landmarked clubhouse is but another chapter in the history of a club with perennial financial problems. The rights would be used by a developer to erect a 37-story apartment house over the the rear section of the club, originally built as a ladies' annex.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE designation of Frank R. Jones as the new interim supervisor of Islip demonstrated anew the continuing power of Anthony Pace, the Islip Republican leader, and represents a Suffolk version of the recent political ups and downs in Nassau County.

LEAD: The young J. Edgar Hoover saw him as a threat to the American way, plotted to deport him on subversion charges and finally succeeded in having him convicted of mail fraud. But millions of others called him ''Black Moses,'' flocked to his Harlem speeches on racial pride and poured money into his ''all Negro'' steamship line founded to ''link colored peoples all over the world.

LEAD: Jane Tavernor Battle, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Cullen Battle of Charlottesville, Va., was married yesterday to David Douglas Richards, a son of Cynthia Richards of Duxbury, Mass., and Douglas Richards of Springfield, Vt. LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''M ASTERPIECES OF American Folk Art,'' the exhibition that will inaugurate the new Hirschl & Adler Folk gallery this Friday, has already caused both controversy and wide anticipation. Both reactions are linked to the emphasis in the exhibition on pieces that have been auctioned in recent years for record-setting prices, and to the fact that the show of 24 paintings, weathervanes, whirligigs, painted furniture, stoneware, needlework, quilts and chalkware was organized by the temporarily homeless Museum of American Folk

LEAD: To the Editor: We were pleased to read about the Sydney Opera House, which brought back memories of our visit in 1984. We had bought the package ''An Evening at the Sydney Opera House'' before we left. We enjoyed the visit but did have a problem with the guided tour. For those of us who are older and/or arthritic, the numerous steps are an obstacle.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: LUI A View of Him. By Louise Colet. Translated by Marilyn Gaddis Rose. 317 pp. Athens, Ga.: The University of Georgia Press. $24.95.

LEAD: ONCE UPON A TIME, BE-fore Dr. Spock and permissiveness, it used to be said that children should be seen but not heard. Exactly the opposite is what some people like in loudspeakers. They want them to be heard but not seen.

LEAD: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has ordered the Navy to increase its presence near the Persian Gulf in an effort to fulfill President Reagan's pledge to keep oil flowing to allies in Europe and Japan, Pentagon officials said today.

LEAD: THE insurance company that owns Sterling Forest and has been trying to sell the 30-square-mile tract of mountains, lakes and woodlands straddling the New York-New Jersey border has announced that it no longer is actively marketing the property and instead is studying alternatives to a sale, including developing up to 3,000 housing units while still preserving large sections of land.

LEAD: THE LAST TIME AROUND, TWO years ago, there was disco music pounding, a neon sign flashing, sculptures that twirled, collages mixing images from high art and soft porn, and a packing crate filled with embalmed fetal pigs. It was the Whitney Biennial Exhibition, the once-every-two-year show at the Whitney Museum of American

LEAD: Golf International Senior Sweep: The International team captained by Gary Player continued its domination of the $600,000 Chrysler Cup championship yesterday, sweeping the top two places in two-man best-ball medal play to open a commanding 46-20 lead after three rounds of the Senior PGA Tour event in Sarasota, Fla.
LEAD: When Mike Plant left Sydney, Australia Jan. 18 at the halfway mark in his global voyage, he carried with him a spinnaker that was a gift from an America's Cup helmsman.

LEAD: The location scouts for the 1978 remake of the film classic ''Heidi'' had a hard time finding a remote alpine hamlet embodying Dorfli, Heidi's little village. After visiting dozens of sites, they finally discovered exactly what they were looking for: Grevasalvas, a rough farming village tucked away in the Alps.

LEAD: After two years of negotiation, the state has approved a Boston plan to integrate all new housing built with any government assistance, beginning with more than 1,300 units that were started in 1986. Officials are predicting that the plan will have a significant effect on housing patterns.
LEAD: The Pentagon has denied an NBC News report broadcast Friday night that military equipment continued to be sold to Iran after the Reagan Administration had called a halt to such dealings.

LEAD: The State Supreme Court Justice presiding in the trial of two men accused of slashing the face of a model, Marla Hanson, will question a juror Tuesday about a hearsay report that she believed the jury was ''afraid to convict.''
LEAD: Johnny Shiloh With Brian Keith, Kevin Corcoran. Walt Disney Home Video. 90 minutes. $69.95.
LEAD: LA MONTE YOUNG, THE 51-YEAR-OLD American maverick composer, is often called the father of Minimalism, but one could make an equally strong case for him as the father of punk rock.
LEAD: FOR someone who has made many people happy, Pablo Morales is still trying to achieve happiness himself.

LEAD: IN 1979, Erma Bressler, an Orthodox Jewish woman from Brooklyn, was 70 pounds overweight. ''I went to diet doctors, hypnotists and weight reduction programs,'' she recalled. ''No one understood the special eating requirements I had. Even the low-calorie recipes included non-kosher ingredients or mixed milk and meat.

LEAD: ''Kicking the Habit,'' a listing of anti-smoking programs last Sunday in The Good Health Magazine (part 2 of The Times Magazine), misstated the cost of the New York Lung Association's program. The series of six 90-minute sessions costs $40.

LEAD: THE chief attorney for Bernhard H. Goetz, Barry I. Slotnick, stood before a panel of 18 prospective jurors the other day and asked a question that has echoed through the legal system in this country for more than 300 years: ''If you find that the prosecution has proved its case beyond a reasonable doubt .

LEAD: Pablo Morales of Stanford and Matt Biondi of California finished their college championship swimming careers tonight with victories that made the record books. So did John VanSant, a senior from Army, which is hardly a national swimming power.

LEAD: THE guests at a party in New Rochelle ate what they think their ancestors ate in the house where their ancestors lived, at the recent celebration of the awarding of Federal landmark status to the city's oldest house.

LEAD: WE OUGHT TO SIT quietly and think about how we handle Mike,'' wrote Oliver L. North to Bud McFarlane, ''so that he does not start talking out of disgruntlement (if that's a word). . . .''
LEAD: SAVERIO PRINCIPATO may finally find his ideal landlord - someone who leaves him alone - now that city officials have agreed to restrict office conversions in Manhattan's garment district.

LEAD: GOVERNOR O'NEILL, in his State of the State Address in January to the General Assembly, said: ''Let us create the resources to protect the homeless from deathly cold of the lonely streets, to put a roof over the struggling young family and to bring comfort of affordable shelter and care to the frail and the elderly.

LEAD: IN what is considered an unusual legislative initiative, two Westchester lawmakers have released the first section of what they describe as a three-part blueprint for action by the Board of Legislators to benefit the county's older adults.

LEAD: IN the New York Art Theater Institute's dramatization of Edith Wharton's ''Old New York,'' the ensemble's 14 members parade stiffly through the parlor of the Old Merchant's House Museum, 29 East Fourth Street, in 19th-century fancy dress fashioned from foam rubber, cut-up garbage bags and shower curtains.

LEAD: THE stage was clearly a special place at the Bessie Schonberg Theater on Friday night. Miran Mohar had designed a glowing floorcloth for the premiere of Randy Warshaw's ''Fragile Anchor,'' and the six members of the Randy Warshaw Dance Company kept rushing in and whirling about on it.

LEAD: Karen Judith Margolin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Myron H. Margolin of Livingston, N.J., and North Egremont, Mass., was married yesterday to Bruce Efron Seidmon, a son of Maynard Seidmon of Chicago and Pompano Beach, Fla., and Sheila Seidmon of Chicago. Rabbi Azriel Fellner, assisted by Cantor Henry Butensky, performed the ceremony at the Short Hills, a catering center in Millburn, N

LEAD: I want to thank you for some fine journalism in recent weeks. Judith Miller's article ''The Istanbul Synagogue Massacre'' (Jan. 4), Seymour M. Hersh's article ''Target Qaddafi'' (Feb. 22) and Richard Reeves's investigation into the Palme assassination in Sweden are exceptionally well written pieces of journalism, and ones of which you should be extremely proud.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: WHEN AKAJI MARO was casting about for a name for his dance troupe, he hit upon ''camel.'' The animal is misshapen and unattractive -somewhat like the deliberately shocking images Mr. Maro includes in his dances.

LEAD: In 1874, the Sisters of the Good Shepherd bought a huge tract of land in Peekskill, N.Y. During the next century, it evolved into Mount St. Florence, a major convent with a girls' school, stable, dairy and orchard. Now the idyllic setting, on Chapel Hill Drive off Maple Street, is being translated into a 566-unit residential community on 123 acres to be called Chapel Hill

LEAD: If there had been proper research on when Breslau became Lindenhurst, it would not have been erroneously speculated [ ''What's in a Name? History,'' About Long Island, March 1 ] that ''the same sort of wartime sentiment that turned German measles into Liberty measles may have affected the alteration.
LEAD: AS the Long Island Rail Road embarks on still another attempt to improve service, it risks leaving $95 million in Federal funds stranded.
LEAD: Andy Shapiro came home one day in December to find state and local officials congregated in his kitchen.

LEAD: For the last three weeks, lawyers for The Daily News have presented evidence to a Federal jury intended to show that four black employees were victims of their own limitations or improper behavior, not racial bias.
LEAD: Pat Bradley, who has won four of the last five women's major golf tournaments, moved into a tie for the lead today through three rounds of the Nabisco Dinah Shore tournament.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Lohrfink of Yonkers of the engagement of their daughter Alison Gean Lohrfink to David Wayland Blood, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wayland F. Blood of Orchard Lake, Mich. A June wedding is planned.

A plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 2 10 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. (Bantam, $4.95.) A rich, beautiful young woman conquers the world of magazine publishing.
LEAD: HOT colors and hot peppers will soon be sprouting in gardens around the state.

LEAD: CALL it the week of the acquisitive. The world of million-dollar auctioneering had rarely experienced such an overheated display as occurred on a few nights this week, here and in London, in the name of art and romance.

LEAD: The hiring of a private American investigative agency to look into reports of illegal financial activities by Indians overseas has set off a new political dispute for Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi.
LEAD: A WAY OF LOOKING AT THINGS Selected Papers From 1930 to 1980. By Erik H. Erikson. Edited by Stephen Schlein. 782 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $29.95.

LEAD: THE rush is on to plant, rake, feed and seed. Even though the weather is ''iffy'' at times, April is the month to put the garden in order. Rake, feed and seed bare spots in lawns. But tender vegetables and annuals should be kept waiting until next month; this means delay planting of peppers, tomatoes, eggplants and seed of beans, especially limas, corn, squash and melons.
LEAD: Regarding the question in the column ''About Long Island'' [ March 8 ] : ''Has concern for ecology of our fair country - including Long Island - gone too far?'' I respectfully answer no!

''Tent Meeting,'' the new comic play that opens Wednesday at the Astor Place Theater, derives much of its humor from the megalomaniacal showmanship and just plain madness of its revival preacher, the Rev.
LEAD: DUET FOR THREE By Joan Barfoot. 252 pp. New York: Beaufort Books. $15.95.

LEAD: TWO Hudson River villages, Hastings-on-Hudson and Irvington, are grappling with decisions on what to do with their waterfronts. Those waterfronts include some of the county's choicest sites - the kind where millionaires want to live and where developers hope to make their fortunes - with land worth about $100,000 an acre.

LEAD: When Fran Metcalf and her husband, Earl, left a rapidly developing town on the Maine coast to settle here seven years ago, they thought they had found everything they wanted: a huge historic home in a quaint little New England village, a good place to rear their two children.

LEAD: THIEVES have stolen our peace of mind. Returning home one afternoon last week, my little boy and I discovered our door wide open. A muddy sneaker print on the door showed clearly what had happened. In the middle of the afternoon on a clear sunny day a stranger had kicked in our side door.
LEAD: THE 50 or so American soldiers stationed in El Salvador to train Government forces represent just one kind of potentially dangerous military commitment.

LEAD: In the giddy 14 months since the overthrow of the dictatorship of Jean-Claude Duvalier, Haiti has often seemed on the brink of skidding into anarchy. But fears were allayed last week when the citizens of the hemisphere's poorest country overwhelmingly approved a new constitution that promises freedom from the tyrannies that have prevailed for most of its history.

LEAD: At the Red Clay Creek Presbyterian Church in Wilmington, Del., yesterday Michelle Margaret Hill, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J.Milton Hill of Chadds Ford, Pa., was married to Louis Peter Angeli, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Angeli of Wilmington. The Rev. Dr. William Evans performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Marian McPartland, the jazz pianist and composer, will give a master class Tuesday evening at 7:30 at the Manhattan School of Music, 120 Claremont Avenue. She will comment on the performances of student soloists and ensembles, and will illustrate certain points at the piano. The two-hour session is free and open to the public; no tickets or reservations are required.

LEAD: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List FICTION 1 1 3 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 2 2 9 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $18.95.) The nightmarish experiences that befall a woman and her family after her appointment as Ambassador to Rumania.

LEAD: I.B.M. dropped the other shoe last week. Its first line of personal computers imprinted on the industry a standard that was to become international, a standard copied, cloned or counterfeited by countless other firms. Now I.B.M. has about-faced, deserting its own criterion for a brand-new one, albeit one that is also of its own devising.
LEAD: THE ARABS Journeys Beyond the Mirage. By David Lamb. 333 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

LEAD: POSITANO, a restaurant at 240 Park Avenue South, at 20th Street, joined the city's jazz- piano rooms this week. Unlike most of the other piano rooms, which feature piano and bass duos, Positano is using trios -piano, bass and drums.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John E. Porta of Coral Gables, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter Stephanie Stockton Porta to William Eisele, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Eisele of Aurora, Ohio. The wedding will be in August.

LEAD: It's a stop for all trains on the old Orient Express line, but few visitors to Austria get out in Linz, and most foreign motorists on the Vienna-Salzburg superhighway flit past the Linz exit. They apparently do not realize that the city is famous for the Linzer torte , a renowned cake, and that the old section in the center of town is crammed with Renaissance and Baroque buildings, some with plaques commemorating visits by such composers as Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert and the astronomer Johannes

LEAD: UP TO NOW, I HAVE GENERALLY believed that the best way to interest children in architecture is to let them loose in it - to let them experience soaring space, to let them look up to great height, to let them touch and feel materials and textures and decoration. There's still no substitute for the real thing, but a close second is the exhibition, ''Building Buildings'' that was recently mounted at the Staten Island Children's Museum at Snug Harbor.
LEAD: Three years ago, when he was head of nursing at a Houston hospital, Daniel G. Moreschi found himself contemplating a medical nightmare.
LEAD: THE Russians have responded to a long cast from an imaginative band of American fly fishermen.
LEAD: ''Stability, Development, Democracy'' say the election banners strung across Cairo's crowded streets by President Hosni Mubarak's National Democratic Party.

LEAD: NIGHT AS FRONTIER: Colonizing the World After Dark. By Murray Melbin. (Free Press, $19.95.) In his celebrated 1893 essay on the West, Frederick Jackson Turner wrote: ''And now, four centuries from the discovery of America, at the end of a hundred years of life under the constitution, the frontier has gone.
LEAD: A 45-year-old man angry over water leaking into his apartment stabbed his landlord to death yesterday after a dispute erupted in the landlord's Upper East Side office, the police said.
LEAD: DISCOVERIES worth a Nobel Prize and a fortune have ignited a race for glory in a Long Island journal known to few besides physicists.

LEAD: WITH EYELIDS THAT BE-come increasingly heavy with every lost minute, we sit through each Academy Awards telecast to find out who wins what award. We eat and drink as if there's no tomorrow, though tomorrow has already come. We think we're waiting to hear the names of the winners. We assume that's the appeal, but we may be wrong.

LEAD: IN fine vocal shape at the age of 68, Joe Williams is also a witty and articulate repository of jazz lore. The former Count Basie singer, who grew up in Chicago where he worked professionally in the late 1930's and 40's, recently opened a three-week engagement at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street.
LEAD: Michel Goulet and Peter Stastny each scored two goals as the Quebec Nordiques romped to an 8-4 victory tonight over the Devils.

LEAD: THE LONG-AWAITED OPEN-ing of the Toscanini family archives - thousands of scores, books, letters, records and items of memorabilia that have waited 17 years unsorted in a basement while the conductor's heirs dickered with the New York Public Library, and now at last acquired by the library for the benefit of researchers - comes at a moment of something like high drama in the saga of the great Italian conductor's posthumous reputation.

LEAD: BEDSIDE MANNERS: The Troubled History of Doctors and Patients, by Edward Shorter. (Touchstone/ Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) The centuries-old, ever-shifting relationship between doctors and patients ''resembles an intense, stylized and changeable dance'' in this study, Fitzhugh Mullan said in The Book Review last year.

LEAD: ARTS AND CHANGE Philadelphia will be host to a national conference on ''The Arts as a Force for Social Change'' next weekend at Drexel University. The three-day conference, which begins Friday, is dedicated to ''the countless artists, known and unknown, whose voices have been silenced by government repression.

LEAD: IF the progress of music can be defined in terms of a slowly advancing army - one that continually occupies new ground but must look to its flank for nourishment - than many of today's worthwhile composers have leaped perilously ahead of their line of supply.
LEAD: Relations between Israel and the Soviet Union seemed to be moving one step at a time last week, but the two sides could not agree on which way they were headed.

LEAD: FOR apartment-seekers in many sections of the country, this is a season of satisfaction, a time of landlord deals and vacant apartments in abundant supply.
LEAD: REPRESENTATIVE John G. Rowland's idea of recreation is to go to a in the Fifth Congressional District and mix with the crowd.

LEAD: Butler $185,000 103 Summit Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old split-level; two-zone heating, screened porch, family room; taxes $2,005. Lake Hiawatha $118,500 32 Calumet Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; fire place, enclosed porch; taxes $1,142.

LEAD: Brooke Elizabeth Conaty, a senior analyst for the Bond Investors Guaranty Insurance Company in New York, plans to be married May 9 to Thomas Joyce Farley, an assistant vice president in municipal underwriting for Bond Investors Guaranty.

LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the European Space Agency will launch a joint mission to the Sun in October 1990 and send a spacecraft to Jupiter in October or November 1989, officials of the agencies said Friday. Both missions will be launched from the space shuttle, the officials said.
LEAD: EXPORTS are surging. Corporate profits are growing smartly. Productivity is climbing. Strikes are scarce. And this year the economy may grow faster than any other in the industrial world.

LEAD: MY son and I hugged at Kennedy Airport after he and his girlfriend dropped my wife and me there for a business-pleasure weekend in Florida. As always, I informed him that the will was in the drawer near my side of the bed at home and told him to take care of his sisters if something happened. As always, we laughed.

LEAD: BRUCE WOLOSOFF'S evening of piano music at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday was perhaps more imaginative for its planning than its execution. There were, for example, two interesting pieces, one old, one new: the Busoni F-minor Sonata and a new sonata by Richard Danielpour.
LEAD: Dave Johnson, who regularly says that he doesn't like surprises, got a couple of big ones this week.

LEAD: Delays have dropped dramatically at New York's three major airports since air traffic changes went into effect along the East Coast in mid-February, according to the Federal Aviation Administration. But satisfaction with the improvement is tempered with caution about prospects for the heavy summer travel season.

LEAD: ''MUSIC must be a part of the great organic flow,'' Charles Ives said, ''onwards and always upwards, or else it becomes soft in spirit and dies.'' Appropriately, a work by Ives shares the program with newer music at the fifth anniversary concert of Connecticut Composers Inc. on April 14.
LEAD: Electrical controllers - sometimes called the brains of a subway car -have been failing on many of the two newest models in the city's fleet, according to Transit Authority officials.

LEAD: AMERICA'S HEALTH IN THE BALANCE: Choice or Chance? By Howard H. Hiatt. (Cornelia and Michael Bessie/Harper & Row, $18.95.) Health care in the United States is already rationed, Howard Hiatt argues; the country urgently needs a fairer apportioning of resources that will never be limitless. Those whose bills are paid with the help of private or Government health insurance get more than their share, he contends, while more than 35 million Americans - one-third of them children -are left to scramble for medical attention.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: FORGET Ed McMahon. Put Joan Collins and Bill Cosby on hold. Go after Willard Scott.

LEAD: IN a crushing attack that killed an American military adviser and more than 70 soldiers, Salvadoran leftist rebels served rude notice last week that they still intend to wage a long war and block the consolidation of the American-backed Government in El Salvador.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II is scheduled to take part in an ''encounter with the world of labor'' here Sunday morning. But the fishermen of this gritty port city, like many other workers in the economically depressed south of Chile, have had to send their regrets.

LEAD: Although Wagner hardly intended it, ''Parsifal'' and the Easter season have become inextricably linked, and it's that time of year again. While the Metropolitan Opera's 1970 production of the opera is not exactly news, it's still highly recommendable (it will be staged Monday evening and Saturday afternoon, with two more performances next week).
LEAD: Elizabeth Frances McCloskey, a candidate for a master's degree at the Yale Divinity School, and Peter Collins Leibold, a second-year student at the Yale Law School, plan to be married May 30.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Tabas of Haverford, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Kimberly Tabas to Kenneth Lewis Tepper, a son of Debra Gross of the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia and Edward B. Tepper of Villanova, Pa. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: Fistfights broke out at the headquarters of the main opposition party today after about 200 supporters of an opposition legislator stormed in to protest a disciplinary hearing he is facing.

LEAD: ''I WAS TRYING TO COME TO terms with the situation, with AIDS, that's why I wrote it,'' said Harvey Fierstein of ''Safe Sex,'' the trio of one-act plays that will open tonight at the Lyceum Theater. He was speaking softly, and his somber demeanor had none of the inspired outrageousness that theater audiences have come to expect on stage: Harvey Fierstein the streetwise imp, Harvey Fierstein the Jewish mother from Bensonhurst, Harvey Fierstein the drag queen with a heart of gold who overcomes life's absurdities with an industrial-strength voice and a face of India rubber.

LEAD: DOWN IN NEW ORLEANS, the commercial FM rock station WYLD has started a daily afternoon show devoted to New Orleans music, past and present. Last year, in Helena, Ark., the historic live blues show ''King Biscuit Time'' was revived on KFFA. All around the country - in San Francisco, Chicago and Minneapolis, as well as at last night's New York Music Awards - hometown performers are acting proud to be provincial.

In no time at all, Japanese productivity would deteriorate, trade surpluses would vanish and we would all be friends again.

LEAD: In reference to your story about the ''Little Red Schoolhouse'' in Elwood [ Long Island Journal, March 8 ] , please be informed that this is not the ''first'' school in the district. School districts were set up in New York State in 1812 and reformed in 1816.

LEAD: IN a remote valley in northern Honduras, United States Army Reserve engineers, supported by National Guard maintenance technicians and military policemen, are working from sunup to sundown to build a gravel-topped road south from the town of Jocon. With each mile pushed through the rough terrain, the road gives Honduran peasants easier access to the port of Trujillo to the north.
LEAD: Heavy rains and high winds hit the New York City region yesterday, flooding highways, bringing some rivers to flood stage and damaging power lines and trees.
LEAD: An article in Arts and Leisure on March 29 about Argentine films misidentified the director of ''The Official Story.'' He is Luis Puenzo.

LEAD: CHANEL NO. 5. First the perfume. Now . . . the T-shirt? This, of course, is no ordinary T-shirt. If nothing else, its price - $80 at Chanel boutiques - sets it far apart from anything with bunches of fruit on the label. And it has to be one of the few T-shirts that is just as much at home under a full-length mink coat as it is over sweatpants.

Cincinnati's center fielder is so exciting a player that observers are prepared to expect him to hit a home run every time up or stroke a mere single, then steal second, third and home.

LEAD: Underlying a debate that has been raging between Assistant Attorney General William Bradford Reynolds and civil rights advocates over whether racial violence in the country has increased lies a fact that neither side disputes: there are no reliable data on racial, religious and ethnic violence.

LEAD: GOVERNOR Kean, who has no more state elections in his future, is coming under increasing pressure from the Republican majority in the Assembly, which faces its most important election in November.

LEAD: I lived for two years in Sweden, studying its politics and culture, and I found Richard Reeves's somewhat sardonic report, ''The Palme Obsession'' (March 1), flawed in its street-smarts certainty.

LEAD: In one of the first fall and winter showings in New York, shiny seams undulated down the back of a coat, the fronts of some jackets, skirts and a halter-neck dress. If one looked closely, the wavy lines formed a profile. Sometimes the profiles were subtly outlined in black thread on black wool or jersey.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: RILKE was probably right when he wrote that the events of the human body - pain, orgasm, taste, smell -are indescribable. These are events and experiences for which language offers no solution. They cannot be conveyed. The writer falls back from his assault upon these citadels of sensation and contents himself with encircling the body with an array of sentences, besieging it with paragraphs in the hope that he will awaken a connection, however dim, between what his character is feeling and what the reader has felt in his own lifetime.

LEAD: WHEN I was growing up in England we ate grilled fish often. But our choice was limited. Mostly it was mackerel or herring, the inside spread with mustard and the outside rolled in oatmeal. The fish were grilled until crisp and served with a mountain of boiled potatoes and butter. For special occasions there was trout or salmon.
LEAD: Four years ago, the apartment building that Meg Harriman now calls home at 104 St. Mark's Place in Brooklyn was an abandoned eyesore.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Myles J. Ambrose of Washington have announced that their daughter Kathleen Anne Ambrose is to be married May 17 to Barry Edward Carter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Byron Edward Carter of Fullerton, Calif.

LEAD: When you consider that neither fighter will make less than $11 million for their showdown, both Marvin Hagler and Ray Leonard would seem to be winners, with the I.R.S. finishing a close second. The future bride graduated cum laude from Smith College and is a first-year student at the New York University School of Law.

It was the first race of the season for the Crimson, and looking ahead, Jack Rusher, Harvard's six man, said, ''We've just begun.''

LEAD: COULD WE BE WITNESSING THE DECLINE OF the Ives phenomenon? Although Leonard Bernstein's New York Philharmonic program this week brings back the Second Symphony, major performances of the Yankee eccentric's music have become rare enough to deserve comment. Originally, Mr. Bernstein was to have given over his entire program to Ives, pairing the comparatively conventional Second with the monumental Fourth.

LEAD: Chadian tactics that led to the spectacular defeat of 5,000 Libyans at Wadi Dum last week are described in a variety of colorful ways by Chadian, French and American officials in the capital here.

LEAD: Major banks raised the prime rate to 7 3/4 percent, from 7 1/2, an indication that interest rates have bottomed out after a long, slow slide. The increase, started by Citibank, was the first in nearly three years. The prime's importance has faded and is now mostly symbolic, and most analysts said the increase will not be fully felt at the consumer level for some time.

LEAD: The very concept of ''A World Without Nuclear Weapons'' is an illusion. Assume for a moment that all nuclear weapons have been destroyed. Unless the means for building them are also destroyed, or placed under some airtight supervision, a number of nations would still be able to produce them quickly.

LEAD: CRUSADE: The Official History of the American Cancer Society. By Walter S. Ross. (Arbor, $18.95.) Within memory of many Americans the word ''cancer'' was once almost taboo. In obituaries the deceased ''died of a long illness.'' Everyone knew that meant cancer, but it was not polite to say so. The American Cancer Society has been a major force in erasing that taboo, in bringing cancer forcefully to public attention, in convincing physicians that some cancers can be cured, others prevented, and that many lives can be saved by trying.

LEAD: THE GERSHWIN CELEBRATION that closed last Sunday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music was a public service. The double-feature bill of ''Of Thee I Sing'' and ''Let 'em Eat Cake'' offered a new generation the chance to hear great Gershwin songs and to sample two classics of American musical comedy, even if in a telescoped concert version.

LEAD: THE tracks on city streets are a bumpy reminder of an era when trolleys were the principal mode of transportation. That era ended in the state more than four decades ago, when the last trolley gave way to buses.

LEAD: I found the article ''What's in a Name? History'' most interesting, but I must tell you that Las Cruces is still very much alive and well in New Mexico. LEAD: NOW it's the Mets' turn to challenge the syndrome that has afflicted World Series winners in recent years. They begin the challenge Tuesday knowing that none of their eight predecessors has been able to repeat as champion.

LEAD: AS increasing numbers of travelers take to the skies, spurred in part by the airline industry's deeply discounted promotional fares, there has been an accompanying rise in flight delays and cancellations. The summer travel season is expected to compound the problem.

LEAD: NOEL COWARD. THE NAME STILL CONJURES up images of unsurpassed elegance, sophistication and drawing-room wit. It encompasses an age and an attitude that were, after all, very much part of this century. All the more startling, then, to find the effervescent Coward fading still further into the fuzzy dimensions of period pieces, still demonstrating his talent to amuse but, more's the pity, looking somewhat quaint and at times perfectly silly.

LEAD: IN January, Bernan Foods, which for 25 years has marketed hors d'oeuvres primarily through kosher caterers and stores, introduced Bernie's East Bagel Dog, a kosher, all-beef frank encased in bagel dough that will be sold through supermarket chains. For the first time the Newark company is actively pursuing non-kosher consumers, through ads in general circulation publications.

LEAD: NOT too many ensembles with established reputations would devote the better half of a concert to a lengthy new piece by a young composer. But this is just what the Juilliard String Quartet did Wednesday night when it played the String Quartet No. 1 by Christopher James at the Juilliard Theater.

LEAD: When President Reagan arrives here Sunday for a two-day visit he will find his host, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, more careworn than the last time Mr. Reagan was in Canada.

LEAD: For Educational Aid April 6 - The estimated 150,000 Sephardic Jews in this country are aided by the youth-education programs of the American Sephardi Federation, which will benefit from a 7 P.M. premiere showing of the movie ''Sweet Lorraine,'' starring Maureen Stapleton. Following the movie at the Paris Theater on 58th Street, just west of Fifth Avenue, there will be a buffet supper at the Plaza.

LEAD: More than 300 people gathered at Columbia University yesterday for a rally and march against racial violence and to protest the response by the administration and the Police Department to a fight involving black and white students on the campus two weeks ago.

LEAD: Dr. Christine M. Hunt, a fellow in gastroenterology, and Dr. Gregg M. Stave, a resident in internal medicine, both at the Medical College of Virginia Hospitals in Richmond, are planning a September wedding, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Hunt of Virginia Beach, Va., have announced.
LEAD: To the Editor: I very much enjoyed James Barron's article, ''The Royal Progress'' as well as the others on Mary Queen of Scots and Edinburgh.

LEAD: Of course, everybody knows the Great Detective never really died at all. He managed to climb out of the Reichenbach Falls and make his way back to England where he lives still, keeping bees on the South Downs, or so his admirers say.
LEAD: LIKE the Pardoner who peddles fake relics and indulgences in Chaucer's ''Canterbury Tales,'' some career consultants and educational institutions are foisting bad job-hunting advice on women.

LEAD: THE Bible says in Proverbs 13:24, ''He who spares the rod hates his son, but he who loves him is careful to discipline him.'' Citing verses like these, 11 church-affiliated day-care centers in North Carolina balked at a regulation of the state's Child Day Care Commission.

LEAD: Mrs. S. Morgan Henry of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Olivia Peters Henry, to Timothy Philip Gurshin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin W. Gurshin of Newburyport, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: MILES and miles from anywhere, this inhospitable lunar landscape in the northwestern corner of Australia is home to six-foot-high anthills, kangaroos, baobab trees - and the world's largest diamond mining operation.

LEAD: The staff of the National Security Council ran amok in the Iran-contra affair. President Reagan conceded that much even before appointing the Tower board to investigate what happened. The Tower report subsequently warned that the N.S.C. staff, so deeply engaged in hostage ransom and Nicaraguan intrigue, must never again become ''operational.

LEAD: The laws of kashrut, as the Jewish dietary laws are more formally called, constitute a complex set of requirements. The two best-known are the proscriptions against eating pork and shellfish, and against eating milk and meat at the same meal. For food manufacturers, that means that they must not use both dairy foods and meat products in the same item; they are forbidden even to use the same machinery to make milk and meat products unless it has been thoroughly cleaned between uses.

Happily, the open-to-the-public sign is now up for the indoor cycle of four ''Springtime Serenades'' that begins today at 3 P.M.
LEAD: The warm spring weather of the last two weeks has been terrible for Victor and Cindy Putnam and hundreds of other maple syrup farmers in New York State and Vermont.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.
LEAD: SOME of the most desirable apartments in New York City are in fewer than 100 in New York City are in fewer than 100 tives along Park and Fifth Avenues from the East 60's to the East 90's.

LEAD: THE controversial $87.9 billion Federal highway bill included $389 million for Westchester County by 1992 and was crucial to the area's road-and-bridge-repair program this year, according to state and local transportation officials.

LEAD: SOME 12 years ago, Mark Fabiaschi was sitting in the cafeteria of Colorado State University when he spotted a terrific-looking girl in the salad line. He hated salad, but desperate situations require desperate measures. Mr. Fabiaschi got up, edged next to her and indicated that he was crazy about lettuce.

LEAD: THE new Laws of Duplicate Bridge, which came into force on April 1, have no impact on social players. Many of the changes will be unnoticed by the duplicate community. But the law on claims and concessions has been strengthened, requiring any clarifying statement to be made immediately rather than, as happened in a recent national tournament, after prolonged thought.
LEAD: An updated text of the New Testament that avoids the use of ''man'' in references covering both men and women was introduced yesterday by the nation's Roman Catholic bishops.
LEAD: THEY ALL LAUGHED AT CHRISTOPHER COLUMBUS Tales of Medicine and the Art of Discovery. By Gerald Weissmann. 270 pp. New York: Times Books. $17.95.
LEAD: WHEN Ljubomir Ljubojevic uses an opening system that lies outside the mainstream, it is not always easy to know what to make of it.

LEAD: To the Editor: I would have thought it impossible but your writers, James Barron and A. L. Rowse, have done it. They have produced a fascinating, accurate and interesting sketch of the life of Mary Queen of Scots (Travel, Feb. 8) without once mentioning John Knox. Unbelievable but congratulations.

LEAD: OUR large amateur choruses exist in part to provide people the pleasure of communal singing. For that purpose - and to help fill our large midtown concert halls - a steady recycling of the great choral masterpieces seems necessary. But these organizations also serve to explore more unusual repertory.

LEAD: I, too, suffer from Mordecai Richler's obsession with finding errors in film and literature, but I do it for a living (''Cinema Verite,'' Guest Observer, March 8). As continuity supervisor for a television soap opera, part of my job is to make sure the clocks on the wall show a passage of time, insuring the gas tank reads above ''empty'' when we're going to drive a car somewhere, and watching to see if the actor dials enough numbers when making a call.

LEAD: The mornings were blanketed with a soft dew, the afternoons warmed by a generous sun. As the days ambled into nights through February and then March, the Yankee camp seemed serene and peaceful. The theme music could have been a lullaby.
LEAD: There it is, Prospero's island rising in the mist. Will it be there when our plane descends or will it have ''melted into air, into thin air?''
LEAD: For all their spit-and-polish presence inside guard booths, members of the elite Marine Corps battalion who provide embassy security appear to be no more disciplined than the corps as a whole.

LEAD: Josephine Brown is now a travel agent; Priscilla Harrison is a career counselor. Some of their friends are working in restaurants; some have opened businesses of their own. But almost all of them would rather be flying again.
LEAD: TWO appealing young players took over the leading roles in Puccini's ''Boheme'' at the Metropolitan Opera Thursday night.

LEAD: Snow being cleared in Dormont, Pa., where up to eight inches fell. Storm left snow from North Carolina to New York State and temperatures reached record lows from Texas to Florida. Heavy rains in New York metropolitan region flooded roads and brought some rivers to flood stage. Page 36. (AP)

LEAD: If we look into the past, we can find many occasions on which nuclear weapons have actually been abolished. We used to have nuclear antiaircraft missiles - Nike-Hercules and Bomarc - scattered widely around the United States. They are not there now. We used to have nuclear intermediate-range missiles - Jupiter and Thor - deployed in Italy and Turkey.
LEAD: By the time she had adopted her second child, Dawn Smith-Pliner's telephone in Pawlet, Vt., was ringing constantly with calls from friends and strangers asking her how she did it.
LEAD: A mentally handicapped woman who once lived with a man accused of torturing six women and killing two others has been found, ending concern that she might be another victim, the police said.
LEAD: ON a spring day 42 years ago this month, Ann Stringer was soaring east through the skies over war-torn Germany in a Piper Cub when she saw smoke rising from a small village adjacent to a river.

LEAD: LARRY McWILLIAMS, a veteran left-hander bothered in recent seasons by shoulder problems, was released yesterday by the Pittsburgh Pirates in one of the costliest contract buyouts in major league history.
LEAD: On Tuesday afternoon, calmly and quietly, Concepcion Salazar Gonzalez sat explaining the new movement she and other relatives of prisoners have recently formed.

LEAD: Because Kyoto was spared the bombings of World War II that devastated Tokyo, Nagoya, Osaka and other Japanese cities, streets of dark old houses remain intact, pretty much as they were in the 19th century. House-proud Kyoto-ites take care of their seemingly fragile wood, paper and plaster houses and the furnishings within the same way their ancestors have for hundreds of years, often using the same types of equipment, some of it still made by hand within the city.

LEAD: THE eye. From the time nearly a year ago when Sugar Ray Leonard began talking about challenging Marvelous Marvin Hagler for the middleweight boxing championship, people have wondered about the risk to the left eye that required detached-retina surgery nearly five years ago. In training, Sugar Ray sparred with a hooded red headgear that protected the eye.
LEAD: SATORU SHIMAZAKI sought expressive simplicity in the works that the Satoru Shimazaki Dancers presented Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

LEAD: The article, ''Trauma Centers Designated'' [ March 22 ] left a false impression that only those hospitals mentioned in the article were ''special'' based upon their total trauma-care capability.
LEAD: WITH minimal fanfare and a modest new sign, the Summit Art Center was recently renamed the New Jersey Center for the Visual Arts.

LEAD: Science is in many ways a very cooperative venture, but it is also one of the most competitive. As a problem captures the attention of the scientific community, experimental results accumulate, reinforcing and contradicting one another, occasionally reaching a critical mass from which a major discovery emerges.

LEAD: Some members of Congress and intelligence officials say they believe that a new United States Embassy building under construction in Moscow is contaminated with Soviet eavesdropping devices and that the entire $190 million project should be scrapped.
LEAD: IT was a different camp for children that Paul Newman, the actor, and A. E. Hotchner, the author, planned.

LEAD: A CASE can be made for diet books as vessels of one of the great spiritual movements of our time - gospels of the American cult of thin. There is the promise of salvation through short-term deprivation, supplemented, naturally, by vitamins. There is the evangelical style, shimmering with such visions as ''painless'' and ''quick'' and ''forever'' (as in slim forever).

LEAD: WHEN the national televison talk show host Sally Jessy Raphael moves her morning show to New Haven in June she will create a lot of firsts.

Al Holland, who came here without a contract or a guarantee that he would make the club, was told he would not be going north with the team even though he had the lowest earned run average in camp.

LEAD: THIS is a very strange country. It has created an enormous university system in which flourishes, among the omnium-gatherum of things learnable and pursuable, an intense subculture of poetry and fiction writing. The outpouring of literary work is so great as to obscure itself, too great to be attended to with the kind of care a slenderer production would allow.

LEAD: Hae Soon Hahn, a violinist in the Handel Festival Orchestra at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, and Steven Rosenbaum, an associate at the law firm Covington & Burling, both in Washington, were married there yesterday. Rabbi Jeffrey Wohlberg performed the ceremony at Adas Israel Congregation.

LEAD: AUSTRALIA'S stamp program for this year begins with its Australia Day issue. The national holiday celebrates the official beginning of European settlement in Australia in 1788. The event has been marked by Australia Post each year since 1978.

LEAD: The Soviet Union announced today it was expelling four French diplomats and two French businessmen in retaliation for the expulsion of three Russians from France after the French said they had uncovered a high-technology spy ring.

LEAD: To the Editor: I am writing re ''The Road to Fotheringay,'' concerning Mary Stuart. Without either defending or castigating the Queen of Scots' husband, Lord Darnley, I, as a gay man, take offense at A. L. Rowse's unfortunate characterization of him as ''worse than useless'' for his having ''preferred the grooms of Holyrood to his wife, the Queen.

LEAD: MANKIEWICZ TO SPEAK Joseph L. Mankiewicz, the distinguished film director and screenwriter and winner of four Oscars, will speak at 8 P.M. Wednesday at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford where he is a parishioner. His topic is ''Religion and the Movies,'' and according to his wife, Rosemary, ''he only talks for about 20 minutes, then opens the floor to questions - he really likes that.

LEAD: Six boxes of Arturo Toscanini's legacy - a few batons, recordings, scores that show how he retouched Debussy and Wagner, even the draft of an angry letter to Mussolini - are now the property of the New York Public Library. Within months, the material should be available to scholars.

Roper's disclaimer of Government responsibility for the medical atrocities being inflicted on Medicare hospital patients under his department's diagnosis-related-group program is a priceless example of how a literal truth may conceal a monstrous falsehood (letter, March 26).

LEAD: David W. Payne, who became a lawyer after working for years as a Broadway theater manager and in other positions related to the performing arts, died of lung cancer on March 27 at Howard County General Hospital in Columbia, Md. He was 48 years old and lived in San Francisco.

LEAD: IF YOU HURRY - IT IS ONLY on for a few more days - you can catch a delectable show at the Bertha and Karl Leubsdorf Art Gallery in Hunter College (at Lexington Avenue and 68th Street, through Friday). It consists of some 60 caricatures by Max Beerbohm -most of them little known, and a number of them never before exhibited or reproduced.

LEAD: The Mets ended their 26th and final spring training in St. Petersburg today, and also ended 62 years of New York baseball presence in this city on the Gulf of Mexico where Babe Ruth and the Yankees once trained.

LEAD: When the lush valleys north of Baltimore begin to brighten with a soft spring green and the hillsides are dotted with flowering dogwood trees, the steeplechase season begins in Maryland's rolling hunt country, as it has since Colonial days.

LEAD: Penguins may begin making their way to the Central Park Zoo from San Diego as early as this summer, followed shortly by polar bears from Buffalo, sea lions from the Bronx and ants from Cincinnati.

LEAD: REAL RAPE. By Susan Estrich. (Harvard University, $15.95.) Everyone agrees that a woman attacked at knifepoint and forced to have sexual intercourse has been raped. LEAD: Springtime in Washington means two kinds of blossoming, as the Japanese cherry trees explode in a mass of colors and the museums, national sites and restaurants fill up with tourists. Cherry Blossom Week begins today, an event that annually has tourism officials hoping they scheduled it correctly.

LEAD: The marketing mavens have long made a distinction in 35-millimeter camera sales between potential buyers of single-lens-reflexes (SLR) and those more likely to buy fixed-lens, auto-focusing, point-and-shoot cameras. They assume, with some logic, that SLR users are a more advanced breed, interested in the controls and options that can make photography fun and possibly even creative.

LEAD: HE found his way to the familiar chair at the desk in his one-room apartment at a Fairfield County retirement home. ''Shall we read the mail?'' he asked me. ''I have two days' mail here,'' he said, fumbling with a pile of unopened letters.

Mr. Warner and a former Home State president were convicted last month on charges of illegally transferring some Home State investments to a failing Florida securities firm in return for guaranteed profits on their personal accounts at the Florida firm.

LEAD: AS OF TOMORROW MORNING, visitors to the Tate Gallery in London will at last be able to enjoy the J. M. W. Turner bequest to the British nation as Turner meant them to enjoy it - in a separate building named after him and devoted entirely to his work. That this should be done was a condition of the bequest, which was made in 1851 and consisted in all of no fewer than 19,331 works of art, large, small and tiny.
LEAD: This city's large homosexual population will test its political strength Tuesday in a special election to fill the unexpired Congressional term of the late Sala Burton.

LEAD: Motivation is a wondrous thing. Perhaps that is what the Knicks had lacked throughout the season, when winning games seemed almost secondary to the ever-present squabbles between players and coaches - past and present - and among the players themselves. All that is left now for the team is to win - and for various individuals to prove that, at least for them, this miserable season has not been a complete waste.

LEAD: NOW that Lefty Driesell, the former Maryland coach, is out of the running for the basketball job at South Alabama, school officials have been looking high and low for another candidate, and, it seems, finding a prospect at each level. The next step is to decide whether whether to reach up to the pros and hire Bill Musselman of the Rapid City Thrillers, the Continental Basketball Association's coach of the year, or down into the junior college ranks to sign Ronnie Arrow, the San Jacinto coach.
LEAD: TIRED of the daily commuting grind into Manhattan, Carl Ruderman of Westport decided to get above it all. In the summer of 1985, he began to commute by helicopter.

LEAD: Britain's threat last week to oust Japanese financial institutions in retaliation for Tokyo's unwillingness to open its markets to British rivals is misguided and counterproductive, according to bankers and brokers here.

LEAD: When Jan Wallman, the veteran cabaret owner, recently relocated from a snug Greenwich Village hole-in-the-wall to better-appointed quarters at 49 West 44th Street, she took with her a roster of loyal performers who rarely appear anywhere else in New York. LEAD: For six years, President Reagan has practiced desperation budgeting. By crushing Congress between the rock of a swelling defense budget and the hard place of his hostility to new taxes, he has worked to deny it any room for domestic spending. Now, his design for budget paralysis is unraveling. The spotlight last week was on overriding the President's veto of the highway bill.

LEAD: Morris Amchan, a senior prosecutor at the Nuremberg war crimes trials after World War II who was also an attorney for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Navy Department, died Friday in Washington after suffering a heart attack. He was 76 years old.

LEAD: A map Saturday with an article about right-wing vigilantes in the Philippines incorrectly located Baguio, a resort city that has been a site of vigilante activity. It is on the island of Luzon, north of Manila.
LEAD: The clashes that marred Pope John Paul II's visit here have heightened disagreement within the Chilean opposition over the use of violence.

LEAD: The New York Chamber Symphony introduced an appealing new piece by Nicholas Thorne, for bass trombone and orchestra, at the 92d Street Y Saturday evening. ''Songs of Darkness, Power and Radiance'' is the unpromising title (evoking familiar, better ones without achieving their authentic ring, and sounding all too much like a list of the attributes the composer hopes listeners will find in the work), but the concerto impressed as a candidate for wide circulation.

LEAD: The operators of Philadelphia Electric's Peach Bottom nuclear reactor have given new pungency to the phrase asleep at the switch. Those working the night shift regularly nod off while the reactor boringly zaps the energy of neutrons into boiling water. While Pennsylvania sleeps, the reactor operators slumber in big, comfortable chairs with their feet up on their desks, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has learned.

LEAD: Every American visitor staying at a Moscow hotel comes back with the same story. You discover the bathroom has no soap. You say loudly angrily to nobody in particular, ''What kind of backward country is this, no soap in the bathroom!'' And a few moments later, as if by magic, the chambermaid taps at the door bearing a bar of soap.

LEAD: ''STAND-UP SHAKESPEARE'' is, as its subtitle indicates, ''a motley musical'' - heterogeneous rather than homogeneous. As directed by Mike Nichols at Theater 890, the show is, alternately, a felicitous musical entertainment and a self-conscious attempt to lead Shakespeare to make fun of himself.
LEAD: When Jack Klugman was approached about doing television commercials for Monday's Marvelous Marvin Hagler-Sugar Ray Leonard middleweight title fight, he stipulated his deal had to have one perk.

LEAD: When I.B.M.'s first generation of personal computers came out, the cost of buying the operating system - the program that acts as the computer's internal traffic cop, directing the flow of data and instructions - seemed inconsequential. I.B.M. charged about $40 for it; many computer dealers threw it in for free.

LEAD: Officials warned residents today to wash exposed eating utensils and clothing and avoid the residue left when a chemical warehouse fire spewed a toxic cloud Saturday that caused an estimated 10,000 people to flee their homes.

LEAD: Chief Leabua Jonathan, Lesotho's Prime Minister for 20 years before he was ousted in a military coup in January 1986, died today in a hospital in Pretoria, the South African Government reported. He was 72 years old.

LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the European Space Agency will launch a joint mission to the Sun in October 1990 and send a spacecraft to Jupiter in October or November 1989, officials of the agencies said Friday. Both missions will be launched from the space shuttle, the officials said.

LEAD: State Senator Roy M. Blake, a deeply conservative Democrat from Nacogdoches, was long a staunch foe of a state income tax for Texas, even sponsoring a constitutional ammendment to ban it in 1985. But now, as he travels his district in rural East Texas, he says he senses a profound shift.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration has agreed to sell artillery shells made of depleted uranium to Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Bahrain, but it has not notified Congress. Why? Because the sales total less than $14 million and the law requiring that Congress be notified of arms sales abroad does not cover sales of less than that amount.

LEAD: Often the things people treasure have no intrinsic Value whatsoever. Report cards, photographs, bridal bouquets, menus, matchbooks, letters, locks of hair - they are everything to their owners but nothing to anybody else. LEAD: Three Midland boys hunting in a field were electrocuted Saturday when wind blew a metal irrigation pipe they had picked up onto a 7,200-volt power line, the authorities said. The boys were evidently trying to flush out a rabbit hiding inside the pipe. A passer-by told deputies he had seen a pipe in the air with three figures below and then ''saw a big flash,'' said Sheriff Gary Painter.
LEAD: The morning that Dr. C. Everett Koop went to Congress to testify in favor of condom advertising, his wife sent him off with these words: ''Well, I'm glad your mother's dead.''
LEAD: Caesars World Inc. announced a sweeping recapitalization plan yesterday that would award shareholders a special one-time, $25-a-share dividend plus some equity in the restructured company.

LEAD: The Passaic River, swollen by Saturday's rain, crested early today in Wayne, and local officials said they did not expect serious flooding, despite the occasional showers forecast for later today.
LEAD: Treasury auctions this week are confined to the bill market, starting with today's regular weekly sale of three- and six-month issues and ending Thursday with a new one-year issue.

LEAD: ''Gold shares became the hedge, or precaution, against such uncertainties as the fear of inflation, the fall of the dollar, Federal Reserve policy -even the sustained rise in most other equity prices.'' That is how John Van Eck, portfolio manager of the top-performing mutual fund in the first quarter of 1987, explained the latest glitter in precious metal stocks.

LEAD: SHE was not a great dancer or singer, nor was she ravishingly beautiful. Yet Josephine Baker became one of the show-business legends of this century. With a combination of monumental impudence and enormous energy, she evolved into the consummate entertainer, forging the kind of special bond with her audiences that spells stardom.

LEAD: Paying for weapons is a problem for many developing countries, and last December the United States offered 38 foreign governments the option of deferring payments on the difference between current interest -then about 7.4 percent - and the higher rates of up to 14 percent at which their loans had been made.

LEAD: ''Conquering Stage Fright,'' a one-day seminar, is to feature the mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne on Tuesday at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Ms. Horne will discuss her own feelings on the matter during the session, which will be led by Barbara Keller, a pianist and teacher. Admission is $10.

LEAD: In 1975, payroll padding charges against a former Assemblyman from Long Island were dismissed by a judge who declared: ''This defendant has been singled out and indicted for his participation in a practice that has prevailed in this state for decades.'' In short, Albany County Judge John J. Clyne said, the legislator was a victim of selective prosecution.

LEAD: White House officials say Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has been given the task of developing a ''short,'' or final, list of candidates to replace William Webster as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Mr. Meese will submit the list to President Reagan, who then will choose a nominee.
LEAD: It has been the kind of season that the Islanders, along with their exasperated rookie coach, would like to disown.
LEAD: Hans Ericson, former longtime leader of Sweden's teamsters union and one of the country's most controversial labor figures, died Saturday at the age of 59, a doctor reported.

LEAD: The coach who was hired to replace the dismissed coach is not coaching. The new general manager who swore that the last thing he wanted to do was coach is coaching. The big-name acquisition of the season did not produce and is gone. He was replaced by a bigger name who is not producing either. And it turns out that a minor trade has given the team one of their most important players.

LEAD: Rick Rhoden, the best-hitting pitcher in baseball, had a higher batting average with runners in scoring position last season than did Don Mattingly, .318 to .305. When someone at the Yankee camp pointed this out to him the other day, Rhoden, who finished in the cellar with Pittsburgh each of the last three years, merely shrugged and said, ''I needed the runs more than he did.

LEAD: White, Yankelovich, Skelly Consulting Group of New York and Stamford, Conn., announced its existence last week and reported that it is made up of three units. They are the Futures Group of Glastonbury, Conn., and Washington, D.C., which does strategic marketing studies among other things; Stockman & Associates of Greenwich, Conn., consultants in international marketing, technology transfer, brokerage and distribution, and Van Dyk Associates of Washington, consultants on public policy and government affairs.

LEAD: QUESTION: Has anybody ever played for all four major league teams in New York City - the Mets, the Yankees, the Brooklyn Dodgers and the New York Giants? It's never happened, and the person who probably came closest was Sal Maglie, who pitched for the Giants, Dodgers and Yankees in New York before ending his career in 1958, four years before the Mets were born and the first year that the Dodgers and Giants were no longer home teams in New York.

LEAD: A Buick automobile that collided with a wedding party's limousine near here, killing the groom and best man and critically injuring the bride and maid of honor, may have been in a race with another car, the Nassau County police said today.

LEAD: Susan Minot, Mona Simpson and Katha Pollitt are among the writers to read from their works in a benefit for Columbia: A Magazine of Poetry and Prose, on April 16 at 8 P.M. at the West Side Y.M.C.A., 5 West 63d Street. Held in conjunction with The Writer's Voice, the benefit is also to include readings by John Fox, Henri Cole and Nancy Schoenberger.

LEAD: After backing away from a showdown with civilian authorities over human-rights trials, the Argentine military has begun an aggressive public defense of its actions in the anti-subversion campaign known as the dirty war.
LEAD: Swiss voters gave overwhelming approval today to Government-backed proposals to tighten restrictions on refugees and make political asylum more difficult to obtain.
LEAD: Oscar Zimmerman, an American bass player and teacher, died of lung cancer Thursday in Traverse City, Mich. He was 76 years old and lived in Traverse City.

LEAD: IN THE PAST, investors quickly lost interest when software companies failed on promises to deliver computer programs that banks and thrift institutions could use to analyze their lending and financial data rapidly.

LEAD: Patricia Ann Alpert, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Alpert of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Charles Alfred Weil, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Otto Weil of Plandome, L.I. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel.
LEAD: Attempts this weekend to reopen the Beirut airport, closed for two months, have turned into a national controversy and heightened tensions between Moslems and Christians.

LEAD: William E. Phillips, 57-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Ogilvy Group and chairman of its Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide subsidiary, has relinquished the latter title to Kenneth Roman, 56, who has been president of O.&M. The agency, which is the country's fifth largest, is dropping the president's post.

LEAD: Temple Beth Sholom in Haddon Heights, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Hillary Kahn, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. S.Benham Kahn of Cherry Hill, N.J., to Curtis Roth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour L. Morgenroth of Valley Stream, L.I. Rabbi Albert Lewis officiated.

LEAD: Jury selection began yesterday for the trial of 12 men, including a convicted Mafia boss, accused of rigging bids on construction contracts, intervening in union elections and plotting murders.

LEAD: Two sailors were swept from the deck of the Navy submarine Ulysses S. Grant in rough weather today. One man was pronounced dead at a hospital 90 minutes after being plucked from the ocean by a Coast Guard utility boat. Rescuers briefly sighted the second man, but he disappeared. Ruth Dow, a spokeswoman for the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard here, said neither sailor's name would be released until their families were notified.

LEAD: Joan Benoit Samuelson, the Boston Marathon women's record-holder who planned to run in the event this month despite her pregnancy, pulled out of the race yesterday because of a thigh injury. Jack Mahoney, a spokesman for the race, which will be held April 20, said Samuelson had a torn muscle in her right thigh that caused internal bleeding.
LEAD: Nicaragua is negotiating with the Soviet Union to obtain new helicopters in anticipation of increasing warfare, according to Western intelligence reports.

LEAD: Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall today temporarily blocked the deportation of Karl Linnas to the Soviet Union, where the Long Island resident has been condemned to death as a Nazi war criminal.

LEAD: RELYING on new concepts of the human brain, scientists are progressing rapidly in experiments with nerve-cell transplants that promise to halt and perhaps cure a variety of devastating brain disorders.

LEAD: Striking nurses picketed the American Red Cross in two counties today, idling bloodmobiles and seven of 10 donation centers. The union and the nonprofit agency disagreed about how long blood supplies would last.

LEAD: Jack F. Matlock Jr., the new American Ambassador to the Soviet Union, presented his credentials today to President Andrei A. Gromyko and they met privately for half an hour, the United States Embassy reported.
